Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a right common femoral and profunda artery 
Endarterectomy with bovine patch angioplasty. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

WHAT TO EXPECT:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

MEDICATION:
 Take aspirin and Plavix as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions

ACTIVITIES:
 No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
 You should gradually increase your activity
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Redness that extends away from your incision
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions
 

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care!

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

cot:
I25118: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with symptoms of chest tightness and dyspnea on exertion, which are indicative of angina pectoris. The medical record mentions that the patient had a stress echocardiogram and cardiac catheterization revealing multivessel coronary artery disease, leading to the need for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). This supports the diagnosis of atherosclerotic heart disease with other forms of angina pectoris.

I10: The patient is on Losartan, an antihypertensive medication, which suggests a diagnosis of essential hypertension. Although hypertension is not explicitly mentioned in the history, the use of this medication strongly indicates the presence of hypertension.

D62: The patient experienced a significant drop in hemoglobin levels (from 10.0 to 7.6) during the hospital stay, which could be indicative of acute posthemorrhagic anemia, especially given the context of recent surgery.

E785: The patient is on Lipitor, a medication used to manage hyperlipidemia, which is also mentioned in the discharge diagnoses. This supports the diagnosis of hyperlipidemia.

I252: The patient has a history of a prior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), which is documented in the past medical history and discharge diagnoses. This supports the diagnosis of old myocardial infarction.

Z955: The patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with two grafts (LIMA->LAD, SVG->OM), which indicates the presence of a coronary angioplasty implant and graft. This code is appropriate to indicate the presence of the grafts post-surgery.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with hx atrial flutter, EtOH use disorder, opioid 
overdose, 
homelessness (currently in shelter), and CVA in ___, who 
presented with palpitations found to have a.flutter with plan 
for ablation on ___. Unfortunately, patient (while in 
holding area for ablation) declined procedure and left AMA 
without coupon card for anti-coagulation. 

ACUTE ISSUES: 
=============
Atrial flutter and history of CVA.
Patient presented with atrial flutter, currently not adherent to
rate control or anticoagulation medication. Give his recurrent
A.flutter, he was scheduled for TEE and atrial flutter ablation 
___, however on the morning of scheduled procedure he left 
AMA.  At point of exit team was working closely with insurance 
on obtaining coverage for DOAC and had offered him a coupon for 
4 weeks of free eilquis but patient left without this coupon.

#HTN, goal <140/90
Patient SBPs persistently in 130-170s. His agitation and pain 
may have contributed to elevated BPs. Goal SBP<140 given recent 
hx of CVA. Uptitrated lisinopril to 5mg daily. Left AMA prior to 
better control of blood pressure. 

# Substance use disorder
# Homelessness
Patient reported EtOH use disorder and homelessness - currently
residing at ___. Denies hx EtOH withdrawal or
seizures. Patient monitored on CIWA scale, and he did not 
require benzos while inpatient. Social work saw patient and 
offered him rehab, which he declined. 

#L shoulder pain
Patient reporting significant left shoulder pain following 
remote
history of fall. Patient specifically requested Oxycodone 5 mg 
Q4hrs.
His UDS was positive for Opiates and Oxycodone. Of note, prior 
ED visit
for shoulder pain was for his right shoulder. Unable to obtain
clear history for patient as he keeps changing his report. 
Managed without opioids while inpatient with Lidocaine patch, 
Tylenol 1g Q8hr, and Ibuprofen 600 mg Q8hr
PRN. Xray of left shoulder without evidence of acute injury (no 
dislocation, fracture or evidence of arthritis). 

#AMA
Patient articulated his understanding that he would be at risk 
for stroke if he left AMA. He kept repeating that he needed to 
meet friends in ___, but would not elaborate. Psych was 
consulted, but he left AMA prior to them being able to see 
patient. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
[ ] Patient needs coupon for anti-coagulation as he's high risk 
for stroke. Patient willing to take medication, but his 
insurance wouldn't cover it in the past. We attempted to run a 
test script for various anti-coagulation options while he was 
here, but ___ was locked, and he left before we completed 
the process. 
[ ] Patient would benefit from ablation for aflutter. (He also 
has an upcoming ___ appointment with EP in ___ 
[ ] Unclear why patient left AMA. Suspect related to substances 
given he already re-presented to the E.D. just hours after he 
left AMA today. Would get psych involved. ___ also be a 
component of mental disability from prior stroke and history of 
alcohol use disorder. 
[ ] Patient would like benefit from increased dose of lisinopril 
to target SBP <140.

- The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and was drinking three shots of vodka shortly before the onset of palpitations. The patient also has a history of daily consumption of 1 pint of hard liquor and a recent episode of alcohol abuse.

- The patient has a history of opioid use disorder and recently overdosed on heroin, requiring treatment with Narcan. The patient denies further use of heroin but has a positive urine drug screen for opiates and oxycodone.

F17210: Nicotine dependence, cigarettes, uncomplicated

I69934: Monoplegia of upper limb following unspecified cerebrovascular disease affecting left non-dominant side
- The patient has a history of a recent CVA with residual left upper extremity (LUE) weakness and contraction, which is consistent with monoplegia.

Z590: Homelessness
- The patient is currently homeless and residing in a shelter, as mentioned in the medical record.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension
- The patient has persistent hypertension with systolic blood pressures in the 130-170 range. The goal blood pressure is less than 140/90 due to the history of CVA, and the patient was on lisinopril for blood pressure control.

M25512: Pain in left shoulder
- The patient reported significant left shoulder pain, and the X-ray showed no acute injury. The pain was managed with non-opioid analgesics.

Z9181: History of falling
- The patient has a history of falling, which is mentioned in the medical record. However, there is no specific documentation of a recent fall or injury related to falling. This code may not be applicable.

Z7289: Other problems related to lifestyle
- The patient has a documented history of alcohol use disorder and is currently homeless. These lifestyle factors are significant contributors to his overall health and medical issues.

Z590: Homelessness
- The patient"s homelessness is explicitly mentioned in the past medical history and social history sections of the medical record. It is a relevant factor in his care and management.

Z8673: Personal history of transient ischemic attack (TIA), and cerebral infarction without residual deficits
- The patient has a history of a possible CVA (cerebrovascular accident) noted in the past medical history. Although it is not specified whether it was a TIA or a full stroke, the code Z8673 is appropriate to capture this history without residual deficits.

F17210: Nicotine dependence, cigarettes, uncomplicated
- The patient repeatedly expressed a desire to leave the hospital to smoke a cigarette, indicating ongoing nicotine dependence. This is supported by his behavior and the mention of his smoking habit in the medical record.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension
- The patient"s blood pressure readings throughout the hospital stay (e.g., 160/84, 139/103) indicate hypertension. The medical record also mentions that the team was working on his antihypertensive regimen, including increasing his lisinopril dose.

M25512: Pain in left shoulder
- The patient complained of shoulder pain and requested pain medication for his shoulder. This is noted in the review of systems and the discharge physical exam.

F1190: Opioid use, unspecified, uncomplicated
- The patient has a history of opioid use disorder, which is mentioned in the past medical history. There is also a note about a possible recent overdose, although it is not specified whether it was complicated or uncomplicated. The code F1190 is used to capture this history.

Brief Hospital Course:
===============
BRIEF SUMMARY 
===============

___ year old male with PMHx atrial flutter, opioid use disorder, 
recent rib fractures and HTN who presents with palpitations. He 
was noted to be in typical atrial flutter on admission. He was 
give IV Diltiazem and then PO metoprolol and rates decreased to 
___. He was discharged with instructions to follow up with EP to 
plan future ablation. We decided not to perform an ablation in 
house given our concerns with his ability to reliably take 
anticoagulation as an outpatient in the month following an 
ablation. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
# Typical atrial flutter
Has been seen multiple times in the past several weeks with 
palpitations and confirmed atrial flutter. Offered elective 
ablation though has left AMA multiple times before the procedure 
could occur. Etiology for rapid rate may be missed metoprolol 
doses recently. Substance abuse may also be contributing, though 
patient denies recent use (since overdose ___ weeks ago). He was 
restarted on home metoprolol 6.25 Q6h, apixaban 5mg BID. He was 
monitored on telemetry. He gave us his cell phone number as he 
was walking out and requested that he be called with a clinic 
appointment. 

# Opioid Use Disorder
Including alcohol and intranasal heroin with recent overdose for 
which he was hospitalized at ___. Patient denies 
alcohol use since ___. Social work was consulted. The 
patient was offered to speak with addiction psychiatry to 
discuss addiction treatments including initiation of methadone. 
He was interested but decided to leave. He was encouraged to 
follow up with his PCP to discuss initiation of methadone as he 
appeared interested. He was prescribed naloxone on discharge. We 
offered to relay this concern to his PCP but he did not want us 
to discuss the matter with him. 

# Hypertension
Discharged during last hospitalization on 10mg lisinopril though 
left before dose was uptitrated and control was achieved. 
Remained hypertensive in ED and upon arrival to the floor. His 
Lisinopril was increased to 20 mg daily which was continued on 
discharge.

# Rib fractures
Sustained recently after falling on the ice. Patient denies 
syncopal episode. Diagnosed with rib fractures in ___ ED.

# Homelessness
Reported to ED providers that he felt unsafe at his current 
shelter (___). Confirms to me that he no longer wants to 
stay at that shelter. Social work was consulted but the patient 
decided to leave prior to being seen.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[]Will need follow up with Dr. ___ to discuss EP ablation 
given persistent atrial flutter
[]Lisinopril uptitrated to 20 mg daily given persistently 
elevated BPs
[]Although he declined addiction psychiatry consult while 
inpatient, the patient was pre-comtemplative when discussed 
addiction treatment, would definitely benefit from discussing 
this further as an outpatient.

3. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?

I4892: Unspecified atrial flutter
- Reason: The patient presented with palpitations and was diagnosed with atrial flutter. ECGs showed atrial flutter, and the patient was treated with IV diltiazem and oral metoprolol to control the rhythm.

F1110: Opioid abuse, uncomplicated
- Reason: The patient has a history of opioid use disorder, including a recent overdose on intranasal heroin. He was offered addiction psychiatry consultation and naloxone on discharge.

S2241XA: Multiple fractures of ribs, right side, initial encounter for closed fracture
- Reason: The patient sustained rib fractures after slipping and falling on ice. He was diagnosed with rib fractures in the ED, and the pain was consistent with the known rib fractures during the hospital stay.

W000XXA: Fall on same level due to ice and snow, initial encounter
- Reason: The patient slipped and fell on ice, leading to rib fractures. This external cause code accurately describes the mechanism of injury.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension
- Reason: The patient has a history of hypertension and was discharged on lisinopril 20 mg daily to manage his blood pressure.

Z590: Homelessness
- Reason: The patient reported feeling unsafe at his current shelter and was homeless. Social work was consulted, and the patient decided to leave before being seen.

R002: Palpitations
- Reason: The chief complaint was palpitations, and the patient had a history of multiple ED visits for palpitations related to atrial flutter.

Z9114: Patient"s other noncompliance with medication regimen
- Reason: The patient reported missing multiple doses of his medications, including metoprolol, which may have contributed to the recurrence of atrial flutter.

Z8673: Personal history of transient ischemic attack (TIA), and cerebral infarction without residual deficits
- Reason: The patient has a history of a cerebrovascular accident (CVA) in the past, which is documented in the past medical history.

I4891: Unspecified atrial fibrillation
- Reason: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation/flutter, and both conditions are mentioned in the past medical history. However, the current diagnosis is primarily atrial flutter.

F1010: Alcohol abuse, uncomplicated
- Reason: The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder, although he denied recent alcohol use since a specific date. This code captures the ongoing condition.

Z7902: Long term (current) use of antithrombotics/antiplatelets
- Reason: The patient was discharged on apixaban 5 mg BID, an anticoagulant, to prevent thromboembolic events associated with atrial flutter.

E7800: Pure hypercholesterolemia, unspecified
- Reason: This code does not appear to be supported by the medical record. There is no mention of hypercholesterolemia or lipid profile results indicating this condition.

F17210: Nicotine dependence, cigarettes, uncomplicated
- Reason: This code is not supported by the medical record. There is no mention of nicotine dependence or cigarette use in the social history.

I4891: Unspecified atrial fibrillation  
Reason: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation/flutter, and the discharge diagnosis mentions atrial fibrillation. However, the specific type of atrial fibrillation (e.g., paroxysmal, persistent) is not specified in the medical record.

I483: Typical atrial flutter  
Reason: The medical record confirms that the patient has atrial flutter, and ECGs confirmed atrial flutter during this admission. This code is specific to typical atrial flutter.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension  
Reason: The patient"s past medical history includes hypertension, and there is no indication that it is secondary to another condition.

W000XXD: Fall on same level due to ice and snow, subsequent encounter  
Reason: The patient reported a recent fall on ice, which led to a rib fracture. This code is used to indicate the cause of the fall and that it is a subsequent encounter.

S2232XD: Fracture of one rib, left side, subsequent encounter for fracture with routine healing  
Reason: The X-ray confirmed a minimally displaced fracture of the left posterior eighth rib, and the patient is being treated for this condition. The code indicates that it is a subsequent encounter and the fracture is healing routinely.

B1920: Unspecified viral hepatitis C without hepatic coma  
Reason: The patient"s past medical history includes hepatitis C, and there is no mention of hepatic coma in the medical record.

F1010: Alcohol abuse, uncomplicated  
Reason: The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder, and while he denies recent use, there are multiple hospital notes reporting otherwise. There is no indication of complications related to alcohol abuse.

F1110: Opioid abuse, uncomplicated

Z8673: Personal history of transient ischemic attack (TIA), and cerebral infarction without residual deficits

Z590: Homelessness

Z7901: Long term (current) use of anticoagulants

Z888: Allergy status to other drugs, medicaments and biological substances

Z9114: Patient"s other noncompliance with medication regimen

Z813: Family history of other psychoactive substance abuse and dependence

Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE

History of Present Illness:
___ year old male with possible CVA in ___, 
homelessness, alcohol use disorder, opioid use disorder, and 
atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter presents with recurrent 
palpitations.

Please see the numerous other admission notes for this patient 
from the past week. In short, this is a ___ year old patient with 
atrial flutter who has been admitted multiple times with 
symptomatic RVR. He has been planned for ablation procedure at 
least twice and left AMA on the day of the procedure both times
before it could be performed. He most recently left AMA on the 
morning of this admission after being told that his procedure 
may not be able to be done until the following day. 

He represents with similar symptoms of palpitations. ED 
evaluation notable for HR 140s requiring 20mg IV diltiazem with 
good results. He remained hemodynamically stable.

After discussing the case with ED providers, it was felt most 
appropriate to admit this patient again with the hope that a 
definitive procedure could be expedited and hopefully prevent 
recurrent admissions.

Upon arrival to the floor, patient was complaining of rib pain 
from recent rib fracture and requesting oxycodone. He stated 
that his palpitations had resolved at that point. He adamantly 
denies leaving AMA that morning. When asked if he is taking his 
medications, he stated that he had been. When asked how 
frequently he takes his medications, he states "every day." When 
asked if he takes any medications twice per day, he cannot 
remember.

symmetric

IMPRESSION: Mild spontaneous echo contrast but no thrombus in

atrial appendage. Mildly depressed left ventricular and low 
normal right ventricular systolic function in the setting of 
tachycardia. Mild mitral regurgitation. Mild to moderate

aorta and aortic arch.

Findings
rfv ___
typical atrail flutter
terminated after extensive ablation -with 8 mm and stsf adn sro 
sheath
bidirectional block
junctional rhythm

medication non-compliance now admitted for the ___ time in 2.5 
weeks due to leaving AMA prior to planned ablations.

    -Ibuprofen 800mg q8h

    -Deep breathing exercises to prevent respiratory 
complications were again reviewed with patient 

 # Hypertension: stable

Thiamine and Folate supplementation

and Tylenol/Ibuprofen not controlling pain per patient, he has 
reported allergy to Tramadol. Given that he does have documented 
rib fracture he is getting PRN Oxycodone 5mg q6h PRN while 
inpatient. PMP review indicates RX filled for #16 tabs Oxycodone 
on ___ following his visit to ___ ER, did not provide 
additional RX on discharge.   
  
 Psychiatry was consulted, see OMR note from ___, attempted to 
talk about buprenorphine, methadone and Vivitrol and patient was

access to higher levels of care or treatment. 

 Social Work also saw patient, see OMR note from ___, 
recommending OT evaluation to assist with disposition to see if 
he would qualify for SNF or long term care facility. 
 
 OT evaluation reflects that patient would be appropriate for 
discharge with OT services, however given homelessness and 
unable to return to shelter if not fully independent, may 
benefit from STR on discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
 You left the hospital against medical advice before we could
make any further arrangements for your discharge.

 You were admitted to the hospital because you were feeling
palpitations due to your abnormal heart rhythm, atrial flutter. 

 You had an ablation procedure on ___ to attempt to put your
heart back into a normal rhythm. 

 Please follow all instructions regarding the care of the access
sites in the groin and activity restrictions to prevent bleeding
from these areas. 

 Stop taking Metoprolol. Continue all your other medications.

 It is extremely important that you continue to take your
Apixaban (Eliquis) twice daily without interruption to prevent
stroke. Skipping a dose or stopping the medication too early 
puts
you at a high risk for having another stroke. 

 Please continue all other medications as prescribed as listed
with these discharge instructions.

"Patient is a difficult historian due to tangential thought
process. It seems that three days ago, patient was discharged
from ___ after a two month
hospitalization that began at the end of ___. The patient had a

patient's medications to "super sedating levels" to "zonk" him

He
reports that he has been taking his medications "as I am 
supposed
to" but reports that he may not be taking his olanzapine. 

When I ask him why he was brought into the hospital, he tells me
it was because "I felt like I was going to crawl out of my skin"
and then our conversation dissolves into the patient discussing
his discomfort about the impending weather and his housing
situation. Later in our discussion, I asked about if he was
hearing voices and he became quite tearful and emotional saying
that the voices were talking to him today about his housing
situation, accusing him, and this is what triggered him calling
the ambulance due to feeling this discomfort from the voices. He
denies any command hallucinations, ever. Denies feelings of
wanting to harm himself or others. 

Throughout the interview, the patient references concern about
his housing situation, saying he is homeless vs later in the
discussion stating he is about to have a big place. He is also
focused on a girl that he has been dating off and on, named 
___
who is reportedly a ___ for ___. He says he is
single now, but will be dating her soon when he has a place to
stay for the ___. 

Patient asked to give consent for ___ but adamantly

were done there because they were "all wrong" Reviewed ___ reveal Patient was initially at ___ in ___ 
when

to
outpatient psychiatry appointment, but did not call.

been
hospitalized at ___ multiple times. He was admitted to ___
in ___ for ___ research study for ___ stimulation of the
cerebellum in patients with schizophrenia. N-150 protocol."

On interview today, patient remains poor historian due to
disorganization. When patient is asked what brought him into the
hospital he states "Coffee gets me better...I needed a place to
be where I was...I can't survive with just a bottle of
___ is overpriced...I was there and then I wasn't...I
had nothing". It is often difficult to re-orient patient back to
conversation as he is quite tangential and difficult to talk
over. When I specifically ask about the anxiety attack he
reported having yesterday to ED clinicians, . patient states 
that
he feels anxious when "things are not well", "after dark..all 
the
time". He then goes on to say "I feel crazy...horrified", "it's
just another P-A-N-I-C". Of note, patient spells out words
several times during the interview instead of saying them. He
even spells out his last name instead of saying it, stating 
"that
is very personal information that I don't like giving out". 

Patient states he feels "all over the place" but does not 
endorse
depressed mood. He denies hopelessness, stating "No, I have been
in love for the past ___ years". Denies any feelings of guilt,
helplessness, or worthlessness. Denies SI. When asked about HI,
states he does not have thoughts of hurting others but is afraid

further on what he means by this. Endorses AH stating that "they
tell me that the wrong thing to do is the right thing" and they
tell him "others will hurt me". Denies any command AH to hurt
himself or hurt others. When asked about VH, patient states "I
see things that are not there and everything that is always 
there
where I am". Patient feels like he needs help and feels that
hospitalization is appropriate for him.

hallucinations. In the ED the patient endorsed persucatory 
hallucinations centered around his housing situation. On his

mostly related to his housing istuation. The patient has no been

name during interview. Despite history of stalking, the patient

decompensation of his underlying psychotic disorder in the

further aftercare management.

the patient is hospitalized outside of psychiatric institutions.

application had just been filed to compel future antipsychotic

Certainly! Here are the reasons for each of the ICD-10 codes based on the provided medical record text:

**F209: Schizophrenia, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient has a documented history of schizophrenia, and his current presentation includes auditory hallucinations (AH), disorganized thought processes, and paranoia. The diagnosis of schizophrenia is explicitly mentioned in the discharge diagnosis and throughout the hospital course. The specific subtype of schizophrenia is not specified, hence the code F209 is used.

**F419: Anxiety disorder, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient reports experiencing significant anxiety, particularly related to his housing situation and feelings of discomfort. He describes feeling "anxious when things are not well," "after dark," and having a "panic attack" that led to his admission. While the specific type of anxiety disorder is not specified, the general presence of anxiety is noted, making F419 appropriate.

**I10: Essential (primary) hypertension**
- **Reason**: The patient"s past medical history includes hypertension, and this condition is mentioned in the discharge medications (amlodipine 10 mg daily). There is no indication of secondary hypertension, so I10 is the appropriate code.

**B1920: Unspecified viral hepatitis C without hepatic coma**
- **Reason**: The patient"s past medical history mentions hepatitis C, and he denies any active symptoms. The code B1920 is used as the condition is mentioned but not specified further, and there is no evidence of hepatic coma.

**F1290: Cannabis use, unspecified, uncomplicated**
- **Reason**: The patient reports intermittent use of marijuana throughout his life, though he denies recent use. The substance use is documented in the social history, and the code F1290 is used to capture this information without specifying complications.

**Z9114: Patient"s other noncompliance with medication regimen**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of medication noncompliance, particularly with olanzapine and possibly other medications. This is evident from his statements about not taking his olanzapine and the need for a long-acting injectable medication to improve adherence. The code Z9114 captures this aspect of his medical history.

These codes are supported by the detailed information provided in the medical record.

undergoing significant psychosocial stressors. He received

thiamine/folate.  Pt was seen by SW and has supportive family 
with plan for ongoing outpt programs.  Sister (RN) is supportive 
and will help with abstinent programs going forward.  

Acute Alcoholic hepatitis: LFTs improved while in house and 
___ normal.  RUQ US showed echogenic liver consistent with 
steatosis. Other forms of liver disease  including 
steatohepatitis, hepatic fibrosis, or cirrhosis could not be 
excluded. 
Recommend f/u LFTs with PCP after discharge from rehab. 

Anemia secondary to acute blood loss, lower GI bleeding - The 
patient experienced some BRBPR with clots while he was in the 
MICU. He had a Flexaseal, and the bleeding was exacerbated when 
his flexaseal came out. Pt had a history of external hemorrhoids 
which were likely playing a role.  Pt also had initial CT 
imaging with proctitis and colitis.  He was found to have Cdiff 
colitis while in house.  BRBPR resolved over the course of 
hospitalization, he did not require any blood transfusions and 
was having normal BMs by the time of discharge.   

C. difficile colitis:  Pt received PO vancomycin 125mg QID and 
symptoms improved significantly with normal BMS by the time of 
discharge.  Pt is now day ___ for po vanc and will complete 
the course on ___.

Positive blood culture most c/w contaminant: One blood culture 
on ___ grew coag neg staph, but repeat blood cultures have been 
negative for growth.   

Incidental adrenal nodule - indeterminate: Pt will need further 
assessment with nonemergent dedicated adrenal CT/MRI.  This was 
reviewed with the patient and daughter in detail.  Pt expressed 
good understanding of this findings and need for follow up.

TRANSITION ISSUES:
- PCP follow for repeat LFTs and follow up adrenal nodule 
imaging
- Lower GI bleeding and alcoholic hepatitis, recommend GI follow 
up

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS

take for another 2 days, last doses on ___  
7.  Witch ___ 50% Pad ___ID

please give in the morning

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with severe alcohol 
withdrawal,  acute liver injury likely from alcohol abuse and a 
diarrheal infection called C. diff.  You received antibiotics to 
treat the diarrhea and your symptoms have resolved. In addition, 
you were noted to have blood and blood clots in your bowel 
movements.  This was likely caused by internal hemorrhoids.  
Your blood counts were stable, bleeding resolved and you did not 
require any blood transfusions.   Whether there has been 
permanent liver damage is unclear at this time.  Please note, 
one of your scans saw a change (nodule) in your left adrenal 
gland.  It is unclear if this may have an effect on your health, 
but you will need to have a follow up CT scan or MRI of this 
nodule to further evaluate.   Good luck with rehab and staying 
sober.   Please make sure to follow up with your PCP after 
discharge from rehab. 

It was a pleasure to participate in your care,
Your ___ team

cot:
F10239: Alcohol dependence with withdrawal, unspecified: The patient presented with alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including agitation and the need for phenobarbital taper. The history of alcohol abuse and the current episode of withdrawal support this code.

G92: Toxic encephalopathy: The patient had significant withdrawal symptoms requiring phenobarbital and Haldol, indicating acute toxic/metabolic encephalopathy related to alcohol withdrawal.

D6959: Other secondary thrombocytopenia: The patient"s initial labs showed a low platelet count (Plt Ct-84), which is indicative of thrombocytopenia. The context of alcohol use and liver disease suggests a secondary cause.

E872: Acidosis: The patient had a high lactate level (Lactate-5.8), which indicates lactic acidosis.

A0472: Enterocolitis due to Clostridium difficile, not specified as recurrent: The patient tested positive for C. difficile and was treated with vancomycin and metronidazole, confirming this diagnosis.

D62: Acute posthemorrhagic anemia: The patient experienced BRBPR (bright red blood per rectum) with clots, which resolved over the course of hospitalization. This is consistent with acute blood loss anemia.

E519: Thiamine deficiency, unspecified: The patient received IV thiamine for possible Wernicke"s encephalopathy and was later switched to oral thiamine, indicating a concern for thiamine deficiency.

K7010: Alcoholic hepatitis without ascites: The patient had elevated liver enzymes and imaging showing hepatic steatosis, consistent with alcoholic hepatitis.

N400: Benign prostatic hyperplasia without lower urinary tract symptoms: The patient has a history of BPH, which is mentioned in the past medical history.

F17210: Nicotine dependence, cigarettes, uncomplicated: The patient is prescribed a nicotine patch, indicating ongoing nicotine dependence.

E279: Disorder of adrenal gland, unspecified: The CT scan revealed an incidental adrenal nodule, which needs further evaluation.

K648: Other hemorrhoids: The patient has a history of external hemorrhoids, which likely played a role in the BRBPR.

R0902: Hypoxemia: The patient was tachypneic and had diffuse crackles on physical exam, suggesting hypoxemia, although this is not explicitly stated in the final report. However, the presence of cardiomegaly and mild bibasilar atelectasis on CXR supports this code.

History of Present Illness:
___ man with PMH of HTN, ETOH use in remission and tobacco use 
presented with 24 hours of substernal chest pain. He first 
noticed the pain yesterday morning (___) when he woke up. The 
pain continued intermittently throughout the day, despite his 
efforts to rest. He attributed these symptoms to congestion from 
smoking. This morning, the pain was worse and was radiating to 
the jaw. He also developed diaphoresis and some nausea and went 
to the ED. He had never had pain like this before and did not 
take any daily medication. Denies abdominal pain, vomiting, 
diarrhea, fevers, chills, shortness of breath. He has been 
coughing. Patient's history and EKG concerning for acute STEMI. 
Code STEMI was called immediately from triage. Cardiology 
arrived promptly at the bedside. 

In the ED,  
- Initial vitals were:  Temp 97, HR 95, BP 189/141, RR 18, 95% 
RA
- Exam notable for: diaphoresis  
- Labs notable for:  Troponin 0.09
- Studies notable for: 
  EKG: NSR, rate 86, left axis deviation, ST elevations in leads 
V2 through V6, < 1mm ST elevations in leads I and aVL 
- Patient was given:  324 aspirin, 180 ticagrelor, heparin 
bolus, SL nitro with minimal relief, and nitro drip.

After initial evaluation in the ED, the patient was taken 
urgently to cath lab for revascularization via right radial 
access. He had total occlusion of the mid-LAD. He underwent 
stent placement without complications.

On arrival to the CCU, the patient appears anxious. He is having 
chest pain ___. He is completely surprised by this event. He 
says that he has never had chest pain like this before, and 
thought his symptoms were related to smoking. He denies 
exertional chest pain. He did note that over the past six 
months, he has had dyspnea on exertion and occasional orthopnea 
that improves with sitting up. He can climb about 20 steps 
before he
has to stop and catch his breath. He has also noticed weight 
gain
during this time as well: he usually weights about 180 lbs, and
recently his weight had gone up to 210. He denies any swelling 
in
his legs or abdomen. He has a history of heart disease in his
family: father had MI in his ___ and CABG. 
He has no known medical problems otherwise. He recently saw a 
PCP
for smoking cessation. He also had an outpatient sleep study 
done
with results pending. He takes no medications at home.

negative.

___ TRANSTHORACIC ECHOCARDIOGRAM
The left atrial volume index is normal. There is no evidence for 
an atrial septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. The estimated right 
atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with a normal cavity size. There is 
moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
severe hypokinesis to akinesis of the mid to distal anterior, 
anteroseptal, septal walls and distal LV/apex (see schematic) 
and preserved/normal contractility of the remaining segments. No 
thrombus or mass is seen in the left ventricle. Quantitative 
biplane left ventricular ejection fraction is 45 %. Left 
ventricular cardiac index is low normal (2.0-2.5 L/min/m2). 
There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. 
Tissue Doppler suggests an increased left ventricular filling 
pressure (PCWP greater than 18mmHg). There is Grade II diastolic 
dysfunction. Mildly dilated right ventricular cavity with focal 
hypokinesis of the apical free wall. The aortic sinus is mildly 
dilated with normal ascending aorta diameter for gender. The 
aortic valve leaflets (?#) are mildly thickened. There is no 
aortic valve stenosis. There is no aortic regurgitation. The 
mitral valve leaflets appear structurally normal with no mitral 
valve prolapse. There is trivial mitral regurgitation. The 
tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is 
physiologic tricuspid regurgitation. There is mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion.

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
moderate regional systolic dysfunction most consistent with LAD 
distribution coronary artery disease, with mildly depressed 
ejection fraction. Elevated PCWP and diastolic dysfunction 
suggested. Right ventricular apical hypokinesis. Mild pulmonary 
hypertension.

Compared with the prior TTE (images reviewed) of ___, LV 
regional wall motion abnormalities are present and systolic 
function is lower.

___ CORONARY ANGIOGRAPHY AND PCI
The coronary circulation is right dominant.

LM: The Left Main, arising from the left cusp, is a large 
caliber vessel. This vessel bifurcates into the Left Anterior 
Descending and Left Circumflex systems.

LAD: The Left Anterior Descending artery, which arises from the 
LM, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 50% stenosis in the 
proximal segment. There is a 100% stenosis in the proximal 
segment. There is a
40% stenosis in the mid segment. The Septal Perforator, arising 
from the proximal segment, is a small caliber vessel. The 
Diagonal, arising from the proximal segment, is a medium caliber 
vessel.

Cx: The Circumflex artery, which arises from the LM, is a large 
caliber vessel. The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the 
proximal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. The ___ Obtuse 
Marginal, arising from the mid segment, is a medium caliber 
vessel.

RCA: The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is 
a large caliber vessel. The Acute Marginal, arising from the 
proximal segment, is a small caliber vessel. The Right Posterior 
Descending Artery, arising from the distal segment, is a medium 
caliber vessel. The Right Posterolateral Artery, arising from 
the distal segment, is a medium caliber vessel.

 The LAD had mid total occlusion, crossed and dilated then 
stented with 0% residual. proximal 50% left alone. Diag was 
compromised (70% stenosis) by stent, and was dilated with 2.0 mm 
balloon with 40% residual

TTE ___
-----------------
CONCLUSION:
The left ventricle has a normal cavity size. There is mild 
regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with near 
akinesis of the distal inferior and septal walls and mild 
dyskinesis of the apex (see schematic) and preserved/ normal 
contractility of the remaining segments. The visually estimated 
left ventricular ejection fraction is 50%. Normal right 
ventricular cavity size with focal hypokinesis of the apical 
free wall.
IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular cavity size with regional 
biventricular systolic dysfunction most c/w CAD (distal LAD 
distribution).
Compared with the prior TTE (images reviewed) of ___, the 
findings are similar.

Brief Hospital Course:
=================
SUMMARY STATEMENT
=================
___ man with PMH of HTN, ETOH use in remission and tobacco use 
presented with 24 hours of substernal chest pain, found to have 
anterolateral STEMI, now status post PCI to mid LAD.

====================
ACUTE MEDICAL ISSUES
====================
#ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction
No history of chest pain. Risk factors include family history, 
active smoking, obesity. Initial EKG with ST elevations in I, 
AVL, and V2-5 consistent with anterolateral infarct in LAD 
territory. Troponin peaked to 6.34. He underwent placement of 
Promus ELITE stent to the LAD on ___. He will need repeat 
lipid panel in 3 months to ensure LDL <70. Would also recommend 
HBA1C and cardiac rehab in 6 weeks time.

Lipids notable for Chlesterol 180, HDL 47, Calculated LDL 107. 
ACEi: Lisinopril 10 mg 
Neurohormonal Beta-Blockade: Metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily
Statin: Atorvastatin 80 mg daily
Antiplatelet agents: Clopidogrel 75 mg daily, Aspirin 81 mg 
daily

#Acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
#Apical Akinesis 
His TTE was notable for LVEF 45% with apical akinesis and he was 
therefore started on warfarin with goal INR ___ for LV thrombus 
prophylaxis. He was continued on aspirin 81mg daily. Although he 
was initially treated with ticagrelor 90mg BID, this was 
converted to Plavix 75mg daily (after 150mg load) after his 
apical akinesis was discovered. A contrast TTE found no LV 
thrombus. He did not require diuretic therapy while 
hospitalized. 

======================
CHRONIC MEDICAL ISSUES
======================
# Hypertension
Per patient, he was formerly taking HCTZ but has not taken it 
for some time. Arrived to CCU on nitro gtt, though continued to 
by hypertensive to 170/120s, necessitating addition of 
captopril. His blood pressure was subsequently better 
controlled. His discharge regimen was Lisinopril 10 mg daily and 
metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily.

# Tobacco use
Smokes about 1 pack/day. Working with PCP on smoking cessation 
prior to admission. He was treated with a nicotine patch, 14 
mg/day (lower dose due to CV disease).

# History of alcohol use
Last used in ___, was drinking 2 pints liquor/daily. Has 
previously been admitted for withdrawal requiring phenobarbital 
but no seizures of DT. Denies recent use. Did not have any 
symptoms of withdrawal on this admission.

# Leukocytosis
Suspect likely inflammatory reaction secondary to STEMI. No 
localizing signs of infection and no fevers.

# Transaminitis
AST elevation likely secondary to infarct and cell necrosis, 
although with previous EtOH misuse history could represent 
underlying baseline liver dysfunction. Admission ALT/AST were 
69/313, trended down to 46/136.

===================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[ ] Patient is amenable to smoking cessation and should be 
provided with further resources for this - discharged with 14 
mcg patches 
[ ] repeat ECHO to see if apical akinesis has recovered, 
discharged on warfarin (2.5 mg daily) not therapeutic at 
discharge, but no indication for bridging 
[ ] Follow with ___ clinic 
[ ] LFTs found to be abnormally elevated, which may warrant 
periodic monitoring 
[ ] Arrange Sleep clinic ___ to evaluate results of recent sleep 
study, likely requires PAP (was intermittently hypoxic w/ normal 
Xray and exam)
[ ] F/U with PCP for smoking cessation and medication management 
(will need INR monitoring)as well as repeat lipid panel and A1C 
in ___
[ ] F/U with Cardiology for post-STEMI care
[ ] Cardiac rehab in 6 weeks, no acute ___ needs

cot:
I2102:ST elevation (STEMI) myocardial infarction involving left anterior descending coronary artery
- Reason: The patient presented with chest pain and was diagnosed with an anterolateral STEMI, confirmed by EKG showing ST elevations in leads V2 through V6, and < 1mm ST elevations in leads I and aVL. The coronary angiography revealed a total occlusion of the mid-LAD, which was stented during the PCI procedure.

I110:Hypertensive heart disease with heart failure
- Reason: The patient has a history of hypertension and was found to have acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (LVEF 45%) and apical akinesis, consistent with hypertensive heart disease complicated by heart failure.

I5021:Acute systolic (congestive) heart failure
- Reason: The patient was diagnosed with acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (LVEF 45%) and apical akinesis, indicating systolic dysfunction. The TTE showed moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and a mildly depressed ejection fraction.

I2510:Atherosclerotic heart disease of native coronary artery without angina pectoris
- Reason: The patient has a history of atherosclerotic heart disease, as evidenced by the presence of significant stenoses in the coronary arteries (50% stenosis in the proximal LAD, 100% stenosis in the mid LAD, and 40% stenosis in the mid LAD). The patient did not report a history of angina pectoris.

E785:Hyperlipidemia, unspecified
- Reason: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia, and his lipid profile showed cholesterol 180, HDL 47, and calculated LDL 107. He was prescribed atorvastatin 80 mg daily to manage his hyperlipidemia.

G4733:Obstructive sleep apnea (adult) (pediatric)
- Reason: The patient has a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and a sleep study was pending at the time of admission. The discharge instructions included follow-up with a sleep clinic to evaluate the results of the sleep study.

D72829:Elevated white blood cell count, unspecified
- Reason: The patient had an elevated white blood cell count (WBC 11.3) on admission, likely due to an inflammatory response secondary to the STEMI. There were no localizing signs of infection or fever.

R740:Nonspecific elevation of levels of transaminase and lactic acid dehydrogenase [LDH]
- Reason: The patient had elevated liver enzymes (AST 313, ALT 69) on admission, which trended down to AST 136 and ALT 46. The elevation was likely secondary to the myocardial infarction and cell necrosis, although the history of alcohol misuse could also contribute to underlying liver dysfunction.

F17210:Nicotine dependence, cigarettes, uncomplicated
- Reason: The patient has a history of tobacco use, smoking about 1 pack per day. He was working with his primary care physician on smoking cessation and was treated with a nicotine patch (14 mg/day) during his hospital stay.

F1011:Alcohol abuse, in remission
- Reason: The patient has a history of alcohol use, previously consuming 2 pints of liquor daily, but had not drunk since admission. He has a history of alcohol abuse and has been in remission.

Z7902:Long term (current) use of antithrombotics/antiplatelets
- Reason: The patient was discharged on clopidogrel 75 mg daily and aspirin 81 mg daily, both of which are antithrombotic and antiplatelet agents.

Z7901:Long term (current) use of anticoagulants
- Reason: The patient was started on warfarin 2.5 mg daily for LV thrombus prophylaxis due to apical akinesis and reduced ejection fraction.

Z8249:Family history of ischemic heart disease and other diseases of the circulatory system
- Reason: The patient has a family history of ischemic heart disease, specifically his father had a myocardial infarction and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

The patient did have slightly low blood pressure while working 
with physical therapy on postoperative day 3.  He was given a 
bolus of normal saline with improvement of his systolic blood 
pressure to the 120's. 

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical 
incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or 
abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical 
therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and 
repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was 
acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral 
regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and 
the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. 

 
Mr. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting 
nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy 
lifting until follow up appointment.  Mobilize frequently

Physical Therapy:
WBAT
Posterior hip precautions x 2 months post-op
Wean form assistive ambulatory device as able
Mobilize frequently
Treatments Frequency:
Dry sterile dressing changes daily
Monitor incision for erythema/drainage
Ice to operative extremity
Staples to be removed ___ by ___

Brief Hospital Course:
#Diffuse SAH / ACA aneurysm 
On ___, the patient underwent diagnostic angiogram with coiling 
of the right ACA A1 segment. She was started on a 21 day course 
of Nimodipine for prevention of vasospasm. Post angio head CT on 
___ was stable. She underwent TCDs daily to monitor for any 
signs of vasospasm. CTA on ___ was negative for vasospasm. 
TCD's on ___ and ___ were negative for vasospasm with mildly 
elevated velocities in the right MCA and left ACA. On ___, she 
underwent a repeat angiogram which demonstrated that the 
aneurysm was well coiled and there was no residual as well as no 
vasospasm. She remained neurologically intact throughout the 
remainder of her stay. She was discharged on Nimodipine to 
continue for a full 21 day course. 

#Hyponatremia  
Upon admission, the patient's serum sodium level was 132. She 
was started on hypertonic saline, and salt tabs for goal Na 
135-145. She continued to have high urine outputs and 
hyponatremia and was also started on florinef 0.1mg BID. 
Florinef and salt tabs increased on ___. On ___, she was 
started on standing daily potassium. On ___ the hypertonic 
saline drip was discontinued. Magnesium was repleted and 
potassium chloride was increased to ___ MEQ po daily. The patient 
remained off of the 3% HTS gtt as of ___ with a stable serum Na 
of 130. Her sodium levels continued to improve slowly. Florinef 
was discontinued on ___ after morning sodium resulted at 134. 
Labs on day of discharge demonstrated stability. She was 
discharged on salt tabs and with close follow up with her 
primary care provider. 

#Hypokalemia 
Throughout the patient's admission, he serum potassium levels 
were found to be low, requiring medication with potassium for 
repletion. She was started on standing daily potassium 
supplementation. Potassium chloride was increased to 60 meq po 
daily. On day of discharge patient did not require repletion. 

#Respiratory insufficiency  
While in the ICU, the patient was found to have mild hypoxia in 
the setting of being a current smoker. She was started on 
supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation of 90-95%. She 
returned to her baseline of maintaining appropriate oxygen 
saturation on room air. 
 
#Nausea/vomiting:  
The patient was started on Zofran 4mg IV q8h to manage her 
nausea. Her nausea improved, and she no longer required 
medication. 

#Urinary Tract Infection
The patient was found to have a urinary tract infection and was 
therefore started on a course of PO Ciprofloxacin from 
___. 

#C. Difficile Colitis
The patient was experiencing symptoms of diarrhea, and therefore 
she was tested for C. diff colitis. This was positive, and 
therefore she was treated with PO Flagyl from ___ to 
___.

I606: Nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage from other intracranial arteries
- Reason: The medical record clearly states that the patient presented with diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and underwent diagnostic angiogram and coiling of the right ACA A1 segment aneurysm. This indicates a nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage from an intracranial artery.

E222: Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone
- Reason: The patient had hyponatremia upon admission, with a serum sodium level of 132. She was treated with hypertonic saline, salt tabs, and florinef, which are typical treatments for SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion). The high urine output and difficulty in managing serum sodium levels further support this diagnosis.

A047: Enterocolitis due to Clostridium difficile
- Reason: The patient was diagnosed with C. difficile colitis, as evidenced by positive testing for C. difficile. She was treated with metronidazole (Flagyl) for this condition.

R0689: Other abnormalities of breathing
- Reason: The patient had mild hypoxia while in the ICU, requiring supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation between 90-95%. This indicates an abnormality in breathing.

N390: Urinary tract infection, site not specified
- Reason: The patient was found to have a urinary tract infection and was treated with a course of oral ciprofloxacin.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension
- Reason: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia (HLD), which is often associated with hypertension. Although not explicitly mentioned, it is a reasonable assumption given her other cardiovascular risk factors.

Z720: Tobacco use
- Reason: The patient was noted to be a current smoker, which is documented in the social history section.

E876: Hypokalemia
- Reason: The patient had low serum potassium levels throughout her admission, requiring supplementation with potassium chloride.

R0902: Hypoxemia
- Reason: The patient had mild hypoxia in the ICU, requiring supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate oxygen saturation.

E785: Hyperlipidemia, unspecified
- Reason: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia (HLD), which is documented in her past medical history.

R112: Nausea with vomiting, unspecified
- Reason: The patient presented with nausea and vomiting accompanying her headache. She was treated with Zofran (ondansetron) for these symptoms.

R51: Headache
- Reason: The chief complaint of the patient was a sudden onset headache, which led to her presentation and subsequent diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

B9620: Unspecified Escherichia coli [E. coli] as the cause of diseases classified elsewhere
- Reason: This code is not applicable based on the information provided in the medical record. There is no mention of E. coli causing any specific disease or infection. The urinary tract infection was specifically attributed to C. difficile colitis. Therefore, this code should not be included.

Ms. ___ is a ___ female with the past medical
history noted below who presented with abdominal pain. Her story
began in ___ when she was admitted to ___ with
hematochezia. On upper endoscopy, she was found to have
non-bleeding duodenal ulcers, and these were attributed to 
recent
naproxen use. CT abdomen/pelvis at the time also showed
osteosclerotic findings concerning for metastatic disease. She
was encouraged to follow up with her PCP, but never did. The 
___ prior to admission she developed severe chest pain 
that migrated to 
mid-abdominal region. It was so bad, she couldn't eat. She
presented to ___ again where repeat abdominal imaging 
again
showed osteosclerotic changes and this time a large annular soft
tissue mass in the mid to distal transverse colon. She reported
barriers to accessing care, including difficulty with
transportation. Therefore she was transferred to ___ for 
expedited
oncologic workup and pain control. She reports very watery
diarrhea with occasional blood.

suggesting instead bronchial inflammation, retained secretions 
or in chronic bronchial stricture or relaxation atelectasis. 

Colonoscopy
Impression:

ischemic colitis is a diagnostic possibility, although the 
mesenteric arteries appear patent with mild atherosclerotic 
calcifications.  Although interval increased distension of this 
segment compare to CT from ___ argues for more 
benign etiology, underlying malignancy cannot be excluded.  
Endoscopic evaluation is recommended. 
2. No additional acute process within the abdomen and pelvis. 
3. Diffuse sclerosis of the bones is of unclear etiology.  
Differential 
includes diffuse metastatic disease, hematologic malignancy, or 
metabolic 
disorders.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with past medical history 
notable for hypertension, type two diabetes and prior GI bleed 
from NSAID induced peptic ulcer disease in ___. She 
presented to ___ with abdominal pain. At that time, she 
had a CT abd/pelvis showing possible metastatic osteosclerotic 
lesions diffusely in her bones as well as large 7.5cm colonic 
mass concerning for malignancy. On EKG, the patient was also 
found to be in atrial fibrillation without any known history of 
arrhythmia.

At this point, she was transferred to ___ for expedited 
malignancy work-up on ___. She was initially on the ___ service, where GI was consulted for 
colonoscopy. During colonoscopy, she was found to have no 
malignancy, but rather necrotic appearing colonic tissue 
concerning for ischemic colitis. The colorectal surgery was 
consulted and the patient underwent diagnostic laparoscopy with 
lysis of adhesions on ___. During this procedure, she was 
found to have ischemic appearing tissue without evidence of 
non-viability. No resection was performed and she was 
transferred to the surgical service for post-operative 
monitoring. Of note, she did have mild atherosclerotic disease 
found in her mesenteric arteries and etiology of her ischemic 
colitis was felt most likely to be ischemia from acute on 
chronic hypoperfusion, with some concern for embolic phenomenon 
(lower suspicion) due to paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

The cardiology team was consulted and the patient underwent a 
transthoracic echocardiogram. The echocardiogram was unrevealing 
and demonstrated a structurally normal heart with ejection 
fraction of 55-60%. As the patient remained in sinus rhythm 
during her hospitalization at ___ and lack of symptoms, the 
cardiology team recommended arranging ___ of hearts holter 
monitor as an outpatient and to discuss anticoagulation with her 
primary care physician. The holter monitor lab was contacted at 
___ who reported they had no ___ of hearts monitor at that 
time. The patient was carefully instructed to follow up with her 
primary care provider once discharged to arrange future cardiac 
monitoring and anticoagulation (patient declined colorectal 
surgery team arranging an appointment with her PCP). 

On ___, the patient was discharged home. At discharge, she 
was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, voiding, and 
ambulating independently. The patient takes Tramadol at home for 
spinal stenosis, however, due to the pain she has from recent 
surgery she will be going home with a few pills of 5mg 
oxycodone. The patient was instructed not to take tramadol and 
oxycodone together as she will be at a high risk of opioid 
overdose. The patient expressed understanding and agreed not to 
take both medications together. She will follow-up in the clinic 
in ___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient 
directly prior to discharge.

dispo

Moderate 
Do NOT take with tramadol

#*8 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  Atenolol 100 mg PO DAILY

5.  NovoLOG Flexpen U-100 Insulin (insulin aspart U-100) 100 
unit/mL subcutaneous TID  
6.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID  
7.  Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Ischemic colitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the ___ 
from ___ with abdominal pain and a CT scan that was 
concerning for a mass. You underwent a colonoscopy where no mass 
was identified but you did have "ischemic colitis" (poor blood 
flow to your colon). You were brought to the operating room for 
a diagnostic laparoscopy where no ischemic bowl was found. When 
you were first admitted, your initial EKG showed atrial 
fibrillation (cardiac arrhythmia). Because this could be a risk 
factor for ischemic colitis, you had an echocardiogram that was 
normal. We attempted to arrange for a cardiac monitor for you 
for when you leave the hospital, however, the cardiology lab did 
not have monitors at this time. Please follow up with your 
primary care provider and make arrangements to have ___ of 
hearts (heart monitor) with a cardiologist.

You have recovered from this hospitalization well, your pain is 
well controlled with oral pain medications and you are 
tolerating a regular diet. You are now ready to be discharged 
home to continued your recovery. 

Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to discharge which is 
acceptable; however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having large amounts of loose 
stool without improvement please call the office or go to the 
emergency room. While taking narcotic pain medications you are 
at risk for constipation, please take an over the counter stool 
softener such as Colace.

If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
at ___:
 fever greater than 101.5
 increasing abdominal distension
 increasing abdominal pain
 nausea/vomiting
 inability to tolerate food or liquids
 prolonged loose stool
 extended constipation
 inability to urinate

Incisions:
You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures.  It is important that 
you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area.

You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub.  
If you have steri-strips (the small white strips), they will 
fall off over time, please do not remove them. Please do not 
take a bath or swim until cleared by the surgical team.

Pain
It is expected that you will have pain after surgery, this will 
gradually improve over the first week or so you are home.  You 
should continue to take 2 Extra Strength Tylenol (___) for 
pain every 8 hours around the clock. Please do not take more 
than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or any other medications that 
contain Tylenol such as cold medication. Do not drink alcohol 
while taking Tylenol.  You may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg 
every 8 hours for 7 days, please take Advil with food. If these 
medications are not controlling your pain to a point where you 
can ambulate and perform minor tasks, you should take a dose of 
the narcotic pain medication oxycodone.  Please do not take 
sedating medications or drink alcohol while taking the narcotic 
pain medication. Do not drive while taking narcotic medications. 
Do NOT take tramadol and oxycodone together.

Activity
You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. Do not lift greater than a gallon of milk for 3 weeks. 
At your post op appointment, your surgical team will clear you 
for heavier exercise.  In the meantime, you may climb stairs, 
and go outside and walk.  Please avoid traveling long distances 
until you speak with your surgical team at your post-op visit.  

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care, we wish 
you all the best! 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Certainly! Here are the reasons for the ICD-10 coding based on the provided medical record:

**K55041: Focal (segmental) acute infarction of large intestine**
- **Reason:** The patient was diagnosed with ischemic colitis, which is a form of focal acute infarction of the large intestine. The medical record mentions that the patient had "necrotic appearing colonic tissue concerning for ischemic colitis" during colonoscopy and laparoscopy.

**K551: Chronic vascular disorders of intestine**
- **Reason:** The patient"s ischemic colitis is believed to be due to chronic hypoperfusion, indicating a chronic vascular disorder of the intestine. The medical record states, "etiology of her ischemic colitis was felt most likely to be ischemia from acute on chronic hypoperfusion."

**I129: Hypertensive chronic kidney disease with stage 1 through stage 4 chronic kidney disease, or unspecified chronic kidney disease**
- **Reason:** The patient has hypertension (HTN) and elevated creatinine levels, suggesting chronic kidney disease. The medical record shows multiple instances of elevated creatinine (e.g., 1.2, 1.3 mg/dL), which can indicate chronic kidney disease.

**I480: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation**
- **Reason:** The patient was found to be in atrial fibrillation during her hospital stay, and this was noted to be paroxysmal. The medical record states, "On EKG, the patient was also found to be in atrial fibrillation without any known history of arrhythmia."

**N189: Chronic kidney disease, unspecified**
- **Reason:** The patient has elevated creatinine levels and a history of hypertension, which are indicators of chronic kidney disease. The exact stage is not specified in the medical record, making this code appropriate.

**E1122: Type 2 diabetes mellitus with diabetic chronic kidney disease**
- **Reason:** The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2) and elevated creatinine levels, which suggest diabetic chronic kidney disease. The medical record mentions both conditions.

**Z794: Long term (current) use of insulin**
- **Reason:** The patient is on insulin therapy, as indicated by the discharge medications list, which includes "NovoLOG Flexpen U-100 Insulin (insulin aspart U-100) 100 unit/mL subcutaneous TID."

**D631: Anemia in chronic kidney disease**
- **Reason:** The patient has anemia, as evidenced by low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels (e.g., Hgb-8.6, Hct-27.7). These findings, combined with the presence of chronic kidney disease, support the diagnosis of anemia in chronic kidney disease.

**Z87891: Personal history of nicotine dependence**
- **Reason:** This code is not supported by the provided medical record. There is no mention of nicotine dependence or smoking history in the patient"s medical record. Therefore, this code is not applicable.

cot:
K559: Vascular disorder of intestine, unspecified
- **Reason**: The patient presented with symptoms and imaging findings consistent with ischemic colitis. The CTA showed circumferential wall thickening of the colon at the splenic flexure, which is a common site for ischemic colitis due to its watershed location. The colonoscopy also revealed ulceration and scarring consistent with ischemic colitis. However, the specific subtype of ischemic colitis is not specified, hence K559 is used.

I129: Hypertensive chronic kidney disease with stage 1 through stage 4 chronic kidney disease, or unspecified chronic kidney disease
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease (CKD). Her creatinine levels are consistently around 1.3-1.4, which is indicative of CKD stage 2. The code I129 is used to capture the comorbidity of hypertension and CKD.

E1122: Type 2 diabetes mellitus with diabetic chronic kidney disease
- **Reason**: The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and chronic kidney disease (CKD). The creatinine levels and the history of CKD indicate that the diabetes is contributing to the kidney disease, hence the use of E1122.

N182: Chronic kidney disease, stage 2 (mild)
- **Reason**: The patient"s creatinine levels are consistent with CKD stage 2, which is classified as mild chronic kidney disease. The code N182 accurately reflects this stage of CKD.

Z90710: Acquired absence of both cervix and uterus
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of hysterectomy due to fibroids, which indicates the acquired absence of both the cervix and uterus. This is documented in the past medical history, and the code Z90710 is appropriate.

I480: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation noted on a previous EKG, although no atrial fibrillation was observed during the current hospitalization. The code I480 is used to document the personal history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

Z87891: Personal history of nicotine dependence
- **Reason**: There is no direct evidence in the medical record to support the use of this code. The patient"s smoking status is not mentioned, and there is no documentation of nicotine dependence. Therefore, this code may not be applicable.

M48061: Spinal stenosis, lumbar region without neurogenic claudication
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of lumbar spine stenosis, which is documented in the past medical history. There is no mention of neurogenic claudication, so the code M48061 is appropriate.

E860: Dehydration
- **Reason**: The patient presented with abdominal pain and hematochezia, and it was noted that she had poor oral intake and watery diarrhea, which can lead to dehydration. The initial labs show a high urea nitrogen (BUN) to creatinine ratio, which can be indicative of dehydration. The patient was given IV fluids, further supporting the diagnosis of dehydration.

K5730: Diverticulosis of large intestine without perforation or abscess without bleeding
- **Reason**: The colonoscopy revealed several diverticula in the whole colon, but there was no evidence of perforation, abscess, or bleeding. The code K5730 accurately captures this finding.

K279: Peptic ulcer, site unspecified, unspecified as acute or chronic, without hemorrhage or perforation
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of a prior GI bleed from NSAID-induced peptic ulcer disease. Although this is not the primary issue on the current admission, the history is relevant and should be coded. The code K279 is used to document the unspecified peptic ulcer without hemorrhage or perforation.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___

You were admitted to the hospital after an uncomplicated 
Laparoscopic Colectomy for surgical management of your chronic 
ischemic colitis/stricture. You have recovered from this 
procedure and you are now ready to return home. 
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to discharge which is 
acceptable; however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. However, you may 
have loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old 
appearing blood. If you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having large amounts of loose 
stool without improvement please call the office or go to the 
emergency room. While taking narcotic pain medications you are 
at risk for constipation, please take an over the counter stool 
softener such as Colace.

You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures.  It is important that 
you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area. You may shower; pat the incisions dry with 
a towel, do not rub.  If you have steri-strips (the small white 
strips), they will fall off over time, please do not remove 
them. Please do not take a bath or swim until cleared by the 
surgical team.

Pain is expected after surgery. This will gradually improve over 
the first week or so you are home.  You should continue to take 
2 Extra Strength Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around 
the clock. Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 
hours or any other medications that contain Tylenol such as cold 
medication. Do not drink alcohol while taking Tylenol.  You may 
also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every 8 hours for 7 days. 
Please take Advil with food. If these medications are not 
controlling your pain to a point where you can ambulate and 
perform minor tasks, you should take a dose of the narcotic pain 
medication.  Please do not take sedating medications, drink 
alcohol, or drive while taking the narcotic pain medication. 

You are being discharged home on Lovenox injections to prevent 
blood clots after surgery. You will take this medication for a 
total of 30 days (including doses in hospital), please finish 
the entire prescription. Please monitor for any signs of 
bleeding: fast heart rate, bloody bowel movements, abdominal 
pain, bruising, feeling faint or weak. If you have any of these 
symptoms please call our office or seek medical attention 
immediately. Please avoid any contact activity and take extra 
caution to avoid falling while taking Lovenox.  

You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. Do not lift greater than a gallon of milk for 3 weeks. 
At your post op appointment, your surgical team will clear you 
for heavier exercise.  In the meantime, you may climb stairs and 
go outside and walk.  Please avoid traveling long distances 
until you speak with your surgical team at your post-op visit. 
  
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care, we wish 
you all the best!

inflammation. 
RECOMMENDATION(S):  Follow up MRI with and without contrast 
after resolution of T1 hyperintense blood products.

___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of T1DM,

intense exercise (dragging a barrel up a hill). Only symptom was 
left homonymous hemianopia. Regarding risk factors, her lipids 
are excellent however her diabetes is poorly controlled (9.6%). 
Etiology is most likely hypertensive though given age, history, 
and location, there is suspicious for first amyloid bleed as
