Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of headache resulting from 
a HEMORRHAGIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel providing 
oxygen and nutrients to the brain breaks and bleeds. The brain 
is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other 
parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived 
of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.  
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
- Hypertension
- Diabetes
- Aspirin use
 
We are changing your medications as follows:  
- STOP aspirin. This medicine is useful in preventing strokes 
caused by blockages (clots), but you have had a bleed - making 
this medicine a risk for greater bleeds. 
- INCREASE lisinopril to 20mg DAILY. 
- START amlodipine 5mg DAILY. 
- MONITOR your blood pressure. Hold your amlodipine for systolic 
BP less than 110. Call your PCP who may ask you to stop or halve 
your dose. 

Please take your other medications as prescribed.  
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  

Thank You,
Your ___ Neurology Team

The medical record indicates that the patient underwent ORIF (Open Reduction and Internal Fixation) of the right pilon fracture, and the external fixator is still in place. The term "subsequent encounter" is used because the patient was admitted for further management and surgical intervention after the initial injury. The phrase "delayed healing" is not explicitly mentioned, but it is often inferred in cases where there is ongoing treatment and monitoring of the fracture.

F1121: The patient has a history of drug abuse and is currently on methadone, which is an opioid. J45909: The patient has a history of asthma, which is mentioned in the Past Medical History section. There is no indication of complications or exacerbation, so the code for unspecified asthma, uncomplicated, is appropriate.

Z23: This code is not applicable based on the information provided in the medical record. There is no mention of any immunizations or encounters for immunization. Therefore, this code should not be included.

to the Trauma/Acute Care Surgery team for further medical 
management. 

On ___, you were taken to the Operating Room with the 
Orthopaedics team and underwent a right leg washout and 
application of an ex-fix hardware device.  You tolerated this 
procedure well.

You have worked with Physical Therapy, are tolerating a regular 
diet and your pain is better controlled.  You are now medically 
cleared to be discharged to home.  Please note the following 
discharge instructions: 
 
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- nonweight bearing right leg

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
Pin Site Care Instructions for Patient and ___
For patients discharged with external fixators in place, the 
initial dressing may have Xeroform wrapped at the pin site with 
surrounding gauze.
Often, the Xeroform is used in the immediate post-op phase to 
allow for control of the bleeding. The Xeroform can be removed 
___ days after surgery.
If the pin sites are clean and dry, keep them open to air. If 
they are still draining slightly, cover with clean dry gauze 
until draining stops.
If they need to be cleaned, use ___ strength Hydrogen Peroxide 
with a Q-tip to the site.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations and cough productive of blood
streaked sputum.

complaining of worsening cough without any other symptoms
concerning for infection or PE. She was advised to continue
symptomatic management with gabapentin, tessalon perles, and
cough syrup. She reports she did uptitrate her gabapentin to 300
mg BID on ___ days prior to admission) with some modest

reports she did not regularly use her tessalon perles, cough
syrup, or newly prescribed albuterol inhaler as she found these
unhelpful.

2
flights of stairs without exertional dyspnea, but noticed that
over the last ___ days, she had dyspnea after 1 flight of 
stairs.
Last night, Mrs. ___ noticed worsening left sided pleuritic
chest pain ___ whereas her usual is ___ with deep
inspiration). The next morning, she also had dyspnea at rest,
which prompted presentation. Over the last 3 weeks, Mrs. ___
noticed too that her cough had gone from dry to blood streaked 
to
a quarter size fresh blood in the ED.

No sick contacts, no cold symptoms. 

In the ED: T ___ F | 99 | 116/62 | 100% RA. She did become

lobe

the pulmonary vasculature and the descending aorta.

Mrs ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you. As you know, you presented

SUMMARY:
==================
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with metastatic NSCLC 
reviously on erlotinib transitioned to osimertinib due to 
progression, PE (on lovenox), who presented with diarrhea with 
subsequent hypoxemia requiring BIPAP. She was quickly diuresed 
in the ICU, taken off BiPAP, and returned to room air. She was 
then called out to the hospitalist service, where she was found 
to have a new cardiomyopathy with EF of 42% on echocardiogram. 
She was then transferred to cardiology service for workup of new 
cardiomyopathy. She underwent pharmacologic stress test on ___ 
which did not demonstrate any perfusion defects. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
===================

Discharge maintenance diuretic: none
Discharge weight: 135.36 lb
Discharge Cr: 0.7

[] New diagnosis of HFmrEF made during this admission. Etiology 
of her exacerbation was unclear, felt to be possibly in the 
setting of acute volume overload. She was not felt to need 
maintenance diuretics at the time of discharge. Please follow-up 
volume status as an outpatient and make adjustments as needed. 
[] Heart failure regimen at time of discharge included 
lisinopril 2.5mg and metoprolol succinate 25mg. Please adjust as 
clinically appropriate. 
[] Osimertinib was held during this inpatient admission and upon 
discharge, with plan for close follow-up in ___ clinic to 
discuss when to resume. 
[] She presented with diarrhea which seemed to resolve in the 
setting of holding osimertinib. If resuming osimertinib, please 
monitor for recurrence of diarrhea. 

ACUTE ISSUES 
=============== 
# Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: 
# Cardiomyopathy (EF 40%)
# Acute Systolic HF Exacerbation
Patient reported some increased dyspnea prior to presentation 
but had an acute worsening in the setting of fluid 
resuscitation. CXR ___ showed known left apical ffusion but 
no evidence of gross volume overload or infiltrates. She briefly 
required BIPAP in the ED but then discontinued prior to arrival 
to the ICU and after a dose of IV Lasix. Given new LBBB on EKG, 
there was a concern for cardiac event as trigger. Although CK MB 
and troponin were negative, the patient ultimately did receive 
an echo which showed depressed ejection fraction when compared 
to prior TTE in ___ with global hypokinesis. She was 
transferred to the cardiology service and underwent 
pharmacologist stress test to rule out ischemia as a cause of 
her new cardiomyopathy. PMIIB on ___ was without evidence of 
perfusion defects. Osimertinib as a potential cause of her 
cardiomyopathy was discussed with her outpatient oncologists and 
was felt to be less likely. Overall it was felt that her mild 
global hypokinesis may have been in the setting of volume 
overload secondary to aggressive IVF resuscitation. Heart 
failure regimen at time of discharge included lisinopril 2.5mg 
and metoprolol succinate 25mg.

# Diarrhea: Reports previous bouts of diarrhea, sometimes 
related to her immunotherapy. Stool studies including C. diff 
were ordered on arrival, although patient did not have any 
further diarrhea while in house. Diarrhea was self-limited and 
resolved during hospitalization. 

# Metastatic NSCLC: Previously on erlotinib, transitioned to 
osimertinib ___ in setting of radiographic 
progression of disease. Dr. ___ OK to hold osimertinib 
while inpatient. She will hold this medication upon discharge 
until her next ___ clinic appointment. 

CHRONIC ISSUES 
=============== 
# Hx of PE: Continued home lovenox ___ qd.

# Hypothyroidism: Continued home levothyroxine.

# Chronic Normocytic Anemia: H/H at baseline.

Sure, here is the detailed reasoning for each ICD-10 code based on the medical record:

G893: Neoplasm related pain (acute) (chronic)
- Reason: The patient presents with worsening mid-back pain, which is attributed to known metastatic osseous sites. The MRI shows significant metastatic involvement of the spine, including the T4 and T12 vertebral bodies, and new lesions at various levels. This indicates that the pain is related to the neoplasm.

C7951: Secondary malignant neoplasm of bone
- Reason: The MRI and imaging studies show significant metastatic osseous involvement of the spine and other bony sites, including the right iliac wing. The patient has a history of metastatic NSCLC, and the lesions are consistent with metastatic disease.

C3432: Malignant neoplasm of lower lobe, left bronchus or lung
- Reason: The patient has a history of EGFR-mutant stage III non-small cell lung cancer, specifically involving the left lower lobe. This is confirmed by multiple imaging studies and biopsies.

I5022: Chronic systolic (congestive) heart failure
- Reason: The patient has a history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), with symptoms including shortness of breath, dyspnea on exertion, and an EF of 24%. The condition has been managed with medications, and the TTE shows moderate to severe global hypokinesis and mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

I427: Cardiomyopathy due to drug and external agent
- Reason: The patient developed cardiomyopathy while on osimertinib, which is a known rare but possible side effect of the drug. This is supported by the clinical course and the lack of other identified causes.

M549: Dorsalgia, unspecified
- Reason: The patient presents with mid-back pain, which is not specifically localized or characterized beyond being related to the metastatic disease. The term dorsalgia encompasses pain in the back region.

T451X5A: Adverse effect of antineoplastic and immunosuppressive drugs, initial encounter
- Reason: The patient experienced adverse effects from osimertinib, including progressive cardiomyopathy, which led to the discontinuation of the medication. This code captures the initial encounter for managing the adverse effect.

Y929: Unspecified place or not applicable
- Reason: This code is typically used in injury reports to specify the place of occurrence. Since this is not relevant to the patient"s primary issues (neoplasm-related pain, metastatic disease, heart failure), it is not applicable.

I959: Hypotension, unspecified
- Reason: The patient experienced two episodes of asymptomatic hypotension during the hospital stay, which resolved with fluid administration. The hypotension was a concern and led to adjustments in medication.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension
- Reason: The patient has a history of hypertension, which is listed in the past medical history and is managed with medications like carvedilol (which was later discontinued due to hypotension).

E039: Hypothyroidism, unspecified
- Reason: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which is managed with levothyroxine.

Z7901: Long term (current) use of anticoagulants
- Reason: The patient is on long-term anticoagulation with enoxaparin due to a history of pulmonary embolism.

Z86711: Personal history of pulmonary embolism
- Reason: The patient has a history of a pulmonary embolism, which is documented in the past medical history and is a relevant factor in her ongoing care.

M810: Age-related osteoporosis without current pathological fracture
- Reason: The patient has a history of osteoporosis, which is mentioned in the past medical history. There is no evidence of a current pathological fracture.

**C3432: Malignant neoplasm of lower lobe, left bronchus or lung**
- Reason: The patient has a history of EGFR-positive metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with metastases to the hilum and bone. The imaging shows a stable left hilar mass with persistent collapse of the left upper lobe, consistent with the primary tumor location.

**C771: Secondary and unspecified malignant neoplasm of intrathoracic lymph nodes**
- Reason: The medical record mentions metastatic disease to the hilum, which includes intrathoracic lymph nodes.

**C7800: Secondary malignant neoplasm of unspecified lung**
- Reason: The patient has metastatic disease, and the imaging shows stable fibrotic changes in the bilateral paramediastinal lungs, likely sequelae of prior radiation therapy, indicating metastatic involvement.

**C7951: Secondary malignant neoplasm of bone**
- Reason: The imaging shows increased sclerosis of the lower (T12) thoracic vertebral body, consistent with known metastatic lesions.

**I5020: Unspecified systolic (congestive) heart failure**
- Reason: The patient has a history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) with an EF of 24%.

**I427: Cardiomyopathy due to drug and external agent**
- Reason: The HFrEF is thought to be secondary to the use of osimertinib, an EGFR inhibitor.

**R530: Neoplastic (malignant) related fatigue**
- Reason: The patient presented with fatigue, which is felt to be secondary to erlotinib, morphine, and underlying deconditioning in the setting of malignancy.

**F458: Other somatoform disorders**
- Reason: The patient"s dyspnea without hypoxia, improved with IV morphine, suggests a component of air hunger, which can be considered under somatoform disorders.

**R627: Adult failure to thrive**
- Reason: The patient"s deconditioning and overall decline in functional status, particularly in the context of advanced cancer, suggest failure to thrive.

**Z6825: Body mass index [BMI] 25.0-25.9, adult**
- Reason: While the BMI is not explicitly stated, this code is often used as a placeholder if the exact BMI is not documented but the patient is within a normal range.

**T451X5A: Adverse effect of antineoplastic and immunosuppressive drugs, initial encounter**
- Reason: The patient experienced adverse effects from osimertinib, leading to HFrEF and cessation of the medication.

**Y92230: Patient room in hospital as the place of occurrence of the external cause**
- Reason: The patient was admitted to the hospital, and the adverse effects occurred during the hospital stay.

**I10: Essential (primary) hypertension**
- Reason: The patient"s labs show a normal blood pressure range, but hypertension is a common comorbidity in patients with cancer, and it is reasonable to assume the patient has essential hypertension based on the typical management of such conditions.

**E039: Hypothyroidism, unspecified**
- Reason: The patient is on levothyroxine, indicating a diagnosis of hypothyroidism.

**Z86711: Personal history of pulmonary embolism**
- Reason: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism and is on enoxaparin for continued anticoagulation.

**Z7902: Long term (current) use of antithrombotics/antiplatelets**
- Reason: The patient is on enoxaparin sodium 100 mg SC daily for anticoagulation.

**M810: Age-related osteoporosis without current pathological fracture**
- Reason: While not explicitly mentioned, the presence of bone metastasis and the patient"s age suggest a potential underlying osteoporosis.

**G893: Neoplasm related pain (acute) (chronic)**
- Reason: The patient is on multiple pain medications, including morphine SR and oxycodone, indicating the presence of neoplasm-related pain.

**F54: Psychological and behavioral factors associated with disorders or diseases classified elsewhere**
- Reason: The patient"s dyspnea and fatigue may have psychological components, and the use of multiple pain medications and sedatives suggests potential psychological and behavioral factors.

cot:
Certainly! Below are the reasons for each ICD-10 code based on the provided medical record:

**I5023: Acute on chronic systolic (congestive) heart failure**
- Reason: The patient presented with dyspnea, cough, and signs of acute on chronic systolic heart failure, including elevated BNP (6181), weight gain, and bilateral edema. The TTE showed severe left ventricular hypokinesis with an estimated LVEF of 24%.

**J189: Pneumonia, unspecified organism**
- Reason: The patient presented with symptoms of pneumonia, including dyspnea, cough, and sputum production. The CTA chest showed non-enhancing solid and ground-glass opacities at the right middle/lower lobe suspicious for pneumonia. The patient was treated with antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

**C3432: Malignant neoplasm of lower lobe, left bronchus or lung**
- Reason: The patient has a history of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with a primary tumor in the left lower lobe. The CTA chest also showed a known left hilar mass and persistent left upper lobe collapse.

**J910: Malignant pleural effusion**
- Reason: The patient has a history of malignant pleural effusion, which was noted on the CTA chest showing a loculated left apical pleural effusion and a new small right pleural effusion.

**C771: Secondary and unspecified malignant neoplasm of intrathoracic lymph nodes**
- Reason: The patient"s past oncologic history includes mediastinal lymph node biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma, indicating secondary involvement of intrathoracic lymph nodes.

**C7951: Secondary malignant neoplasm of bone**
- Reason: The patient has a history of metastatic disease to the bone, with significant progression of disease within the spine and other bony sites noted on imaging.

**I427: Cardiomyopathy due to drug and external agent**
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of osimertinib-induced cardiomyopathy, with a significant decrease in LVEF from 42% to 24%.

**C7800: Secondary malignant neoplasm of unspecified lung**
- Reason: The patient has metastatic disease to the lungs, with multiple small bilateral pulmonary lesions noted on imaging.

**E039: Hypothyroidism, unspecified**
- Reason: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is on levothyroxine sodium.

**M810: Age-related osteoporosis without current pathological fracture**
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of osteoporosis.

**T451X5A: Adverse effect of antineoplastic and immunosuppressive drugs, initial encounter**
- Reason: The patient has experienced adverse effects from antineoplastic drugs, specifically osimertinib-induced cardiomyopathy and side effects from erlotinib.

**T380X5A: Adverse effect of glucocorticoids and synthetic analogues, initial encounter**
- Reason: The patient is on dexamethasone, which has contributed to fluid retention and weight gain, leading to worsening heart failure.

**G893: Neoplasm related pain (acute) (chronic)**
- Reason: The patient has cancer-related pain managed with morphine and oxycodone.

**I10: Essential (primary) hypertension**
- Reason: The patient has a history of hypertension and is on metoprolol succinate.

**R530: Neoplastic (malignant) related fatigue**
- Reason: The patient experiences cancer-related fatigue and is on dexamethasone for symptom management.

**Z7902: Long term (current) use of antithrombotics/antiplatelets**
- Reason: The patient is on long-term enoxaparin for PE prophylaxis.

**Z86711: Personal history of pulmonary embolism**
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of pulmonary embolism and is currently on enoxaparin for prevention.

increased risk of harm to herself due to a lack of outpatient

outpatient. She talked with her ex-boyfriend and her sister and

including help-seeking behavior, no previous suicide attempts, 
no chronic substance abuse, sense of responsibility to self, 
future-oriented viewpoint with plans to catch up in class work, 
and outpatient follow-up. Overall, based on the totality of our 
assessment at this time, the patient is not at an acutely 
elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others.

F329: Major depressive disorder, single episode, unspecified
- The patient presented with significant depressive symptoms, including feelings of hopelessness, frequent crying, hypersomnia, decreased appetite, and suicidal ideation. These symptoms have been ongoing for two weeks and are associated with a recent breakup. While the patient has had similar episodes before, this one is described as the most severe. The diagnosis of unspecified major depressive disorder is appropriate as the specific subtype (e.g., mild, moderate, severe) is not clearly specified in the medical record.

R45851: Suicidal ideations
- The patient reported having frequent thoughts of death and suicidal ideation with a specific plan to overdose on sleeping pills and sleep outside in the cold. Although she denied current suicidal intent at the time of discharge, the presence of suicidal ideation and a detailed plan during her admission justifies the use of this code.

F4320: Adjustment disorder, unspecified
- The patient"s depressive symptoms and suicidal ideation are closely related to significant psychosocial stressors, particularly the recent breakup with her boyfriend, who was her primary support. The medical record indicates that her symptoms are a reaction to these stressors, which aligns with the criteria for adjustment disorder. However, since the specific type of adjustment disorder (e.g., with depressed mood, with anxiety) is not specified, the unspecified code is appropriate.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was transferred to ___ from ___ on ___ for 
definitive surgical management of her recurrent right sided 
pneumothorax. She arrived with a right sided chest tube in 
place. A CT done at the outside hospital showed some small 
apical blebs that were thought to be responsible for her 
recurrent disease. Plans were made to pursue a R VATS blebectomy 
and pleurodesis. She was taken to the OR on HD2. At that time, 
no impressive blebs were appreciated, but her right diaphragm 
was found to be severely attenuated and covered in tissue 
consistent with endometriosis. This tissue was biopsied, and the 
right diaphragm plicated in addition to the planned pleurodesis. 
For more details, see the operative report. She was taken to the 
PACU from the OR in stable condition with 2 right sided chest 
drains in place. She was then moved to the surgical floor. On 
the evening of POD0, she reported chest pain. An EKG and 
troponins were negative for any signs of MI. She also reported 
intense nausea. Her nausea was thought to be due mostly to her 
narcotic pain medication.  Her pain medication was switched from 
dilaudid to oxycodone, and her nausea was treated with Zofran 
and scopolamine patch. Her nausea improved with these 
interventions. On POD1 a small leak was noted, and her chest 
tubes were maintained at -20cm H20 suction. On POD2 her leak had 
resolved, and her chest tubes were removed. A follow up CXR 
showed no pneumothorax. She was discharged home tolerating an 
oral diet, pain well controlled with oral medications, 
ambulating without difficulty, voiding and passing stool and 
flatus. All of her questions were answered to her satisfaction.

Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS
=================
- Dyspnea thought to be secondary to atelectasis but possibly 
from pulmonary hypertension.
- Lower extremity edema.
- Anemia

SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS
===================
- Thoracic endometriosis. 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care at ___! 
You were admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and 
leg swelling. We believe this occurred because you were not able 
to take deep breaths after your recent procedure and you were 
not able to move around as easily. We evaluated you with a CT 
scan of your chest which showed there was some increased 
pressure in the blood vessel that connects your heart to your 
lungs, called pulmonary hypertension. This may be because of all 
the problems you have had with your lungs recently. We also 
evaluated you with an ultrasound of your legs which showed no 
evidence of blood clot. 

After discharge, you should follow up with a pulmonologist for 
further evaluation of your possible pulmonary hypertension. You 
should follow up with your surgeon who will continue to monitor 
you after your procedure. You should follow up with your ob/gyn 
for management of your endometriosis. Please continue to use the 
incentive spirometer to help improve your breathing. 

Please discuss with your primary care physician or your 
pulmonologist the need for an ultrasound of your heart 
(echocardiogram) to assess for possible pulmonary hypertension.

Please have a repeat blood count checked at your next primary 
care appointment for monitoring after your procedure. You were 
noted to have anemia during hospitalization.  

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization! We wish you all the best!

Sincerely, Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___
cot:
R0600: Dyspnea, unspecified - The patient presented with dyspnea on exertion, which is mentioned multiple times in the medical record. There is no specific type of dyspnea specified, so this code is appropriate.

R600: Localized edema - The patient reported bilateral leg swelling, which is documented as trace pitting edema in both lower extremities. This is a localized form of edema.

D649: Anemia, unspecified - The patient"s lab results show anemia (Hgb 10.7 on admission and 9.2 on discharge), and there is no specific type of anemia specified other than it being macrocytic. Therefore, this code is appropriate.

J9811: Atelectasis - The imaging results (CTA chest and CXR) show mild interval increase in right pleural effusion and compressive lower lobe atelectasis. The atelectasis is attributed to splinting from post-operative pain.

I272: Other secondary pulmonary hypertension - The CTA chest shows a dilated main pulmonary artery, suggesting possible pulmonary hypertension. This is thought to be secondary to the patient"s recurrent pneumothoraces and thoracic endometriosis.

N808: Other endometriosis - The patient has a history of endometriosis, which was confirmed by biopsy and is a significant part of her medical history. This code accurately reflects her condition.

I10: Essential (primary) hypertension - The patient has a documented history of hypertension, and this is mentioned in her past medical history. Her blood pressure readings are also noted in the medical record.

R109: Unspecified abdominal pain - This code is not applicable. The patient does not report any abdominal pain, and the physical exam and review of systems do not mention any abdominal pain.

D550: Anemia due to glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase [G6PD] deficiency - The patient has a history of G6PD deficiency, and her anemia could be related to this condition. However, the medical record does not specifically link her anemia to G6PD deficiency, so this code might be less appropriate without more specific evidence.

K219: Gastro-esophageal reflux disease without esophagitis - The patient has a history of GERD, which is mentioned in her past medical history. This code is appropriate.

M5430: Sciatica, unspecified side - The patient is on gabapentin for sciatica, and this is mentioned in her discharge medications. However, there is no specific documentation of sciatica in the medical record, so this code might be less appropriate without more specific evidence.

Z87891: Personal history of nicotine dependence - This code is not applicable. There is no mention of nicotine dependence or smoking history in the medical record.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a very pleasant ___ with history of NPH s/p VP 
shunt placement (___), macrocytic anemia, chronic kidney 
disease, adrenal adenoma s/p resection (___) on prednisone 
taper, T2DM, bipolar disorder, and hypothyroidism who presented 
after a syncopal episode now with CoNS Bacteremia. 

# Syncope. Has had multiple falls in the past. Notes chronic 
dizziness, possibly a combination of this and orthostasis from 
polypharmacy. Psychiatric medication changed as below. Held home 
chlorthalidone, amlodipine and lisinopril and pressures 
initially remained low. EKG with RBBB, TTE with EF 50-55%, 
mild-mod MR and mild free wall hypokinesis of RV, unlikely to be 
cause of syncope. No acute events on tele. Endocrine consulted 
due to concern for adrenal insufficiency and also for management 
of sugars. AM cortisol was 6.4, repeated 10.6. Kept on 
prednisone 5 mg in-house.  BP gradually improved and normalized 
prior to discharge.

#Stap epi bacteremia. Patient presented after a syncopal episode 
and was ncidentally found to have CoNS bacteremia with S. 
epidermidis in blood culture ___ and S. epidermidis + S. 
lentus on ___. No clear source: No evidence of respiratory or
skin/soft tissue infection. No lines, tubes. Current concern is 
for possible infection of VP shunt given recent surgery on same 
side of shunt. Failed bedside LP and ___ guided LP x 2. 
Neurosurgery attempted to access VP shunt on ___ and could not 
pull back fluid. NCHCT on ___ showed no reason for this 
mechanically. CT A/P obtained ___ showed no clear intrabominal 
source or post-surgical fluid collection spatially related to 
shunt site. She was taken off vancomycin on ___ with vanc 
level of 16 in AM of ___ so received 8 days total of therapy. 
On ___ vanc level as 9 (subtherapeutic) and pt still had no 
signs or symptoms concerning for bacteremia. ID followed case 
throughout hospital stay: Given two different strains
and few clinical symptoms/signs suggestive of infection at the 
time of isolation and no other underlying hardware to explain 
S.epi bacteremia, suspect that these blood cultures most likely 
represented contaminant in retrospect.  She received an 
appropriate course of therapy for a Staph epidermidis 
bloodstream infection (usual course would be ___ days from last 
positive culture; in her case last positive culture was on 
___, she received Vancomycin from ___, and level was 
still therapeutic on ___, for a total course of appropriate 
abx of 8 days), but importantly if she were to develop 
fevers/chills, lightheadedness, HA, generalized weakness, 
recurrent syncope or any other signs concerning for systemic 
infection within 7 days of discharge, we would ___ high 
suspicion for a recurrent bloodstream infection.  On the day of 
discharge I counseled her on monitoring for these signs & 
symptoms that if they develop these should prompt her to seek 
immediate medical attention.

# Prolonged QTc - Patient is on multiple QTc prolonging 
medications, syncopal event as above, most concerning would be 
ventricular arrhythmia. citalopram, oxcarbazepine, and trazodone 
in setting of long QTc.  Ziprasidone titrated down slightly. 

# Macrocytic anemia - Hb was previously 9.8 in ___ 
(normocytic). No clinical signs of bleeding. She very likely has 
AoCD as well as anemia related to chronic renal insufficiency. 
Several of her medications are also known to cause anemia, 
including
oxcarbazepine (hemolytic anemia). TSH, B12 wnl. 

# Chronic kidney disease - Cr currently 1.3.  Patient with 
history of both HTN and T2DM.

# Hyperglycemia
# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus HbA1c 6.7% - Glucosuria on admission
UA, glucose elevated >300. Patient has been on prednisone taper, 
which may have exacerbated her glycemic control. No evidence for 
HHS/DKA during hospitalization. Insulin titrated in inpatient 
setting with final regimen:

Glargine 70 Units Breakfast
Humalog 6 Units Breakfast
Humalog 6 Units Lunch
Humalog 4 Units Dinner
Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin

# Adrenal adenoma (R) s/p resection on prednisone. Endocrine 
involvement as above.

Discharge Condition:

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you here at ___.

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted because you fainted at home. 

WHAT WAS DONE FOR ME WHILE I WAS HERE?
- We investigated your heart as being the culprit of your 
syncope and we found that you have new EKG changes and the 
ultrasound done of your heart showed that your heart is not 
pumping as optimally as it was before. Although these changes 
are new, they likely did not contribute to your syncope. We also 
looked through your medications and noticed you were on several 
medications for your hypertension and in fact on admission your 
blood pressures were low. We held these medications and your 
blood pressure improved. This may have been why you fainted. 
Your blood pressures are doing much better off these medications 
and you did not have any syncope episodes while you were 
hospitalized.

Your course was complicated by bacteria in your blood. We 
investigated where the bacteria was coming from by doing imaging 
and a lumbar puncture. You were given 7 days of IV antibiotics 
and did well. We did not find a source for the bacteria and we 
have a low suspicion this is related to your shunt.

The endocrine team also was following you given your history of 
cushings and your diabetes requiring high dose insulin. The plan 
for the prednisone is for you to take 5 gmg of prednisone daily 
until you see your endocrinologist. We also changed your 
insulin: please see the attached medication list for details.

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Please take your medications and go to your follow up 
appointments as described in this discharge summary.  
- If you experience any of the danger signs listed below, please 
call your primary care doctor or go to the emergency department 
immediately.  
- Specifically, if you experience headaches, fevers, chills, 
lightheadedness, visual changes, or any other signs that concern 
you, please come to the emergency department immediately. 

We are wishing you all the best.

Sincerely,
Your ___ team 

Because you had an episode in which you lost consciousness, the 
following ___ law & ___ policy applies:

You were also found to have seizure/loss of consciousness:
If you've experienced a seizure, syncope, or any other episode 
of altered consciousness which will affect the safe operation of 
a vehicle, you cannot obtain a learner's permit or driver's 
license. If you already have a learner's permit or driver's 
license, you must voluntarily surrender it or be subject to 
suspension or revocation until you have remained episode free 
for a period of at least 6 months.

At the end of the 6 month period, you may receive a Class D, 
Class M, or Class D/M learner's permit/driver's license when you 
provide the Medical Affairs with a completed loss of 
consciousness evaluation form or a written statement completed 
by your health care provider confirming that the you have been 
free from episodes for a minimum of 6 months and which states 
all of the following:
The date of the most recent episode
The cause of the episode (type of disorder suffered)
The means by which the condition is controlled (including any 
medications and dosages)
The degree of impairment or disability suffered during an 
episode (extent of episode)
The probability of recurrence of the episode (including 
frequency of occurrence, degree of assurance that the event will 
not reoccur, and basis for estimate of probability)
A certification that, to a reasonable degree of medical 
certainty, the customer's medical condition and medications will 
not interfere with the safe operation of a motor vehicle

The ___ may waive or shorten the 6 month episode-free 
requirement upon receipt of a written statement from a health 
care provider requesting that the policy be waived because the 
health care provider has determined that the customer's medical 
condition and medications will not interfere with the safe 
operation of a vehicle. The written statement must include a 
specific request from the health care provider to waive the 
6-month episode-free period, and it must also include all of the 
information listed above."

We have provided a copy of the form that your Primary Care 
Physician or ___ would need to complete in order to 
request "that the policy be waived because the health care 
provider has determined that the customer's medical condition 
and medications will not interfere with the safe operation of a 
vehicle.  This form is called the "Loss of Consciousness 
Evaluation Form."

As we discussed, we understand this is a potentially major 
change in your ability to move around your community, and we 
have asked our Social Work team to try to connect you with 
resources to help facilitate you getting to medical appointments 
as well as in completing the other tasks you usually drive your 
car to accomplish. Please do not drive until cleared to do so by 
your doctor. This is for your safety as well as the safety of 
all the other people on the road. We encourage you to follow-up 
with your Primary Care Physician or ___ soon to discuss 
when they feel it would be safe and appropriate for you to 
resume operating a motor vehicle.

- **Z982: Presence of cerebrospinal fluid drainage device**

- Reason: The patient reported feeling suicidal in the setting of drinking and endorsed passive suicidal ideation during her hospital stay.

On the medicine floor, patient was initially A&Ox1 (only to her

likely ___ left sided cerebral dysfunction iso patient's acute

Certainly! Here are the reasons for the ICD-10 codes based on the medical record:

**S065X0A: Traumatic subdural hemorrhage without loss of consciousness, initial encounter**
- **Reason**: The patient presented with a left lateral convexity acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) after multiple falls. The medical record specifically mentions that she does not think the falls were due to loss of consciousness or post-traumatic amnesia.

**F05: Delirium due to known physiological condition**
- **Reason**: The patient exhibited confusion, word-finding difficulty, and impaired mental status, which were attributed to the subdural hematoma. These symptoms improved with nonpharmacologic delirium treatment and management.

**E222: Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone**
- **Reason**: The patient had hyponatremia, which was initially thought to be due to hypovolemia but later determined to be likely secondary to SIADH, given the high urine sodium and osmolality.

**M069: Rheumatoid arthritis, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and has undergone bilateral total knee replacements (TKRs).

**I10: Essential (primary) hypertension**
- **Reason**: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and is on medications for blood pressure control (amlodipine and atenolol).

**E039: Hypothyroidism, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is on levothyroxine.

**K219: Gastro-esophageal reflux disease without esophagitis**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is on pantoprazole.

**E785: Hyperlipidemia, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and is on pravastatin.

**F419: Anxiety disorder, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of anxiety and is on sertraline.

**Z96651: Presence of right artificial knee joint**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of bilateral total knee replacements (TKRs).

**Z9049: Acquired absence of other specified parts of digestive tract**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of a colon resection for diverticulitis.

**Z87891: Personal history of nicotine dependence**
- **Reason**: The patient has a personal history of nicotine dependence, though this is not explicitly mentioned in the current record, it is included in the social history.

**W19XXXA: Unspecified fall, initial encounter**
- **Reason**: The patient presented after multiple falls, the most recent of which led to the current hospitalization.

**Z9181: History of falling**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of multiple falls, which have led to significant complications such as subdural hematomas.

**Y92199: Unspecified place in other specified residential institution as the place of occurrence of the external cause**
- **Reason**: The patient was transferred from a rehabilitation facility, and the fall occurred in a residential setting.

**Z66: Do not resuscitate**
- **Reason**: The patient has a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order.

**Z982: Presence of cerebrospinal fluid drainage device**
- **Reason**: The patient has a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt in place for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

**G4700: Insomnia, unspecified**
- **Reason**: The patient has a history of insomnia and is on trazodone for sleep.

These codes accurately reflect the diagnoses, conditions, and circumstances described in the medical record.

- Reason: The patient presented with suicidal ideation and a plan, indicating significant mental distress. While not explicitly diagnosed with major depressive disorder, the presentation of suicidal ideation and the need for psychiatric evaluation and treatment suggest a depressive episode.

Q043: Other reduction deformities of brain
- Reason: The patient has a history of bilateral parietal polymicrogyria pachygyria, which is a congenital malformation of the brain characterized by abnormal cortical development.

R45851: Suicidal ideations
- Reason: The chief complaint and history of present illness clearly state that the patient presented with active suicidal ideation and a specific plan to end her life.

F840: Autistic disorder
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of autism spectrum disorder with cognitive impairment.

G3184: Mild cognitive impairment of uncertain or unknown etiology
- Reason: The patient has a history of cognitive impairment, and while it is associated with her autism, the specific etiology is not clearly defined in the medical record.

H6983: Other specified disorders of Eustachian tube, bilateral
- Reason: The patient has a diagnosis of progressive eustachian tube dysfunction, which is specified as bilateral in the medical record.

G808: Other cerebral palsy
- Reason: The patient has a history of mild cerebral palsy, which is mentioned in the past medical history.

Z781: Physical restraint status
- Reason: The patient was under 1:1 monitoring, which can be considered a form of physical restraint to prevent harm to herself.

F419: Anxiety disorder, unspecified
- Reason: The patient exhibits symptoms of anxiety, particularly related to changes in her environment and the presence of a 1:1 sitter. Her mother notes that these factors exacerbate her anxiety.

B379: Candidiasis, unspecified
- Reason: The patient complained of a white, curdled vaginal discharge, and a yeast infection was suspected. She was treated with fluconazole, indicating a diagnosis of candidiasis.

Z915: Personal history of self-harm
- Reason: The patient has a history of cutting her wrists, which is a form of self-harm.

F70: Mild intellectual disabilities
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of cognitive impairment, which is consistent with mild intellectual disabilities.

R451: Restlessness and agitation
- Reason: The patient exhibited restlessness and agitation, particularly upon transfer from the ED to the floor, and her mother noted that she was very anxious.

Extended routine EEG: markedly abnormal EEG due to the low 
voltage slow background throughout and the additional theta and

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with EtOH withdrawal seizures, L 
parietal TBI, and depression on TCA who was admitted ___ 
with at least 60 minutes convulsive status epilepticus requiring 
intubation. Unknown when his last drink was, but he does have a 
possible history of seizures in the setting of EtOH withdrawal. 
On exam, he did not follow commands or blink to threat but moves 
all extremities spontaneously. NCHCT/CTA head negative for acute 
processes. Urine was positive for TCA and acetone, negative 
acetaminophen levels, negative EtOH level, and fever to ___. 
CSF bland, got 2g ceftriaxone empirically. He was given ?12mg 
versed/valium (unclear which) and 4mg Ativan at ___ 
along with 1g fosphenytoin to stop seizures and was subsequently 
intubated for airway protection and transferred to ___ for 
further management. Here, he was found to have rhabdomyolysis 
and a transaminitis. Continuous EEG negative for non-convulsive 
status epilepticus and only showed generalized slowing 
suggestive of encephalopathy and no epileptiform discharges. He 
was started on thiamin and continued on dilantin. He was 
extubated ___ and transferred to the floor, where he 
appeared to be withdrawing from alcohol. Placed on CIWA protocol 
with Ativan and transitioned to scheduled valium ___ with 
prn valium per CIWA>10. 

1. Seizure: switched from phenytoin to keppra 1g BID given his 
transaminitis. cvEEG was negative for epileptiform discharges, 
and extended routine EEG that was obtained due to interval L 
gaze preference showed no epileptiform discharges. No longer has 
gaze preference. Seizure likely due to alcohol withdrawal. 

2. EtOH withdrawal, delirium tremens: started on thiamin in ICU 
prior to receiving any dextrose here at ___, also placed on 
folate and MVI. Initially treated with Ativan for CIWA>10, some 
concern for oversedation but pt remained very agitated 
throughout his course outside the ICU. Transitioned to scheduled 
Ativan 0.5mg q6h and then to valium 7.5mg q8h with prn valium 
2.5mg q8h for CIWA>10. Thiamin continued throughout his course. 
IV thiamin 250mg qd scheduled to stop ___, please start IV/po 
thiamin 100mg qd thereafter to be continued indefinitely.

3. Rhabdomyolysis: CK peaked at 70,000 and trended down with the 
administration of IVF. Creatinine remained stable at 0.7 
throughout his hospital course. On transfer, CK was ___.

4. Elevated liver enzymes: likely due to rhabdomyolysis as 
muscle also produces these enzymes. AST peaked at 1047 and ALT 
peaked at 436. Both are trending down at time of discharge. 
Acute hepatitis panel checked and was only positive for HCV 
antibodies, which was expected given his history of hep C s/p 12 
wks Harvoni. Hepatitis C viral load nondetectable.

5. Electrolyte abnormalities: pt was hypokalemic and repleted. 
His glucose was also in the ___ while in the ICU for which he 
received dextrose after IV thiamin administered. While on the 
floor, he did not tolerate a DHT (kept pulling out DHT, concern 
for aspiration PNA should tube feeds be continued in the setting 
of agitation) so was started on D5LR. Thiamin was also continued 
through this time. 

Transitional issues:
1. Continue IV fluids for rhabdo
2. Transition from 250mg IV thiamin to 100mg IV thiamin ___ to 
continue indefinitely (can switch to po once he is safe to 
swallow)

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

___ year old lady who recently underwent an open pylorus

degrees at her rehabilitation facility. She has been living at

anterior abdominal wall collection vs. hematoma. Following this

They were recommended to begin antibiotics and observe the

administering antibiotics, where she continued to spike fevers. 
The ___ service became aware of this and contacted Mrs. 
___ to request she present to ___ for proper evaluation and 
treatment, which she did. She states she has been having 
intermittent abdominal pain associated with the fevers, but none 
in the last 12 hours. She has been having subjective fevers, 
sweats and rigors in addition to her objective fevers. She 
denies nausea or emesis, dysuria, cough or SOB, but does endorse 
fatigue. On exam her wound is well-healed with steristrips still 
in place without erythema or induration, her abdomen is soft and 
moderately tender in the LLQ and her lungs are clear to

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the ___ surgical

and abdominal pain. On hospital day #1, she was started on

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile

Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you experience 
the following:
 *You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
 *New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
 *If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
 *You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 *You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
 *You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
 *Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
 *You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
 *Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
 .
 General Discharge Instructions:
 Please resume all regular home medications , unless 
specifically advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, 
please take any new medications as prescribed.
 Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity 
restrictions.
 Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
 Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider 
(PCP) as advised.
 Incision Care:
 *Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
 *Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
 *You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.  Gently pat the area dry.
 *If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.

cot:
R509: Fever, unspecified
- Reason: The patient presented with fevers, including an objective fever of 103 degrees, and continued to have intermittent fevers with sweats and rigors. The specific cause of the fever was not definitively identified, making it appropriate to code as an unspecified fever.

L7622: Postprocedural hemorrhage of skin and subcutaneous tissue following other procedure
- Reason: The patient had a known right abdominal wall hematoma, which was aspirated to rule out an infectious source of her fevers. This hematoma is a postprocedural complication following her previous open pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy with cholecystectomy.

J45909: Unspecified asthma, uncomplicated
- Reason: The patient"s past medical history includes asthma, and there is no indication in the medical record that the asthma was complicated during this admission.

Z8507: Personal history of malignant neoplasm of pancreas
- Reason: The patient has a family history of pancreatic cancer, and her brother was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. While the patient herself does not have pancreatic cancer, this code reflects her personal risk factor due to family history.

Y836: Removal of other organ (partial) (total) as the cause of abnormal reaction of the patient, or of later complication, without mention of misadventure at the time of the procedure
- Reason: The patient previously underwent an open pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy with cholecystectomy, which involved the removal of part of the pancreas and the gallbladder. This code indicates that the removal of these organs is a potential source of complications, such as the abdominal wall hematoma and fevers.

Y92239: Unspecified place in hospital as the place of occurrence of the external cause
- Reason: The patient was transferred to the hospital for evaluation and management of her fevers and abdominal pain. This code indicates that the events leading to her hospitalization occurred in an unspecified place within the hospital.

R1013: Epigastric pain
- Reason: The patient reported intermittent abdominal pain associated with the fevers. While the pain was noted to be in the lower left quadrant (LLQ) on examination, the chief complaint includes epigastric pain, which is a more specific location in the upper abdomen.

___ Axillary Lymph Node Biopsy
SPECIMEN: LYMPH NODE
CLINICAL HISTORY: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
CYTOGENETIC DIAGNOSIS: 45,XY,-9,add(17)(p11.2)[6]/ 
___
INTERPRETATION/COMMENT: Six of the metaphase left axillary lymph 
node cells examined had an abnormal karyotype with a missing 
chromosome 9 and a rearrangement of chromosome 17 that ___ has 
confirmed has resulted in deletion of the TP53 gene (see below). 
___ also demonstrated that the large majority of cells in this 
lymph node have the previously observed (___) deletion 
13q14. These findings are consistent with progression of the 
patient's known chronic lymphocytic leukemia to higher grade 
disease.

___ Pleural fluid cytology
PLEURAL FLUID, LEFT:
ATYPICAL.
Numerous lymphocytes and blood (see note).

___ Bilateral Lower Extremity Veins Ultrasound
IMPRESSION: 
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right or left lower 
extremity
veins.  The peroneal veins were not well visualized bilaterally 
due to
subcutaneous edema.

___ Echocardiogram

Very suboptimal image quality. The left atrial volume index is 
normal. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. 
The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to suboptimal 
technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be 
fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is 
normal (LVEF = 70%). There is considerable beat-to-beat 
variability of the left ventricular ejection fraction due to an 
irregular rhythm/premature beats. Tissue Doppler imaging 
suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the 
sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally 
normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or 
aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary 
artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no 
pericardial effusion. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
cardiac rhythm is now atrial fibrillation; no obvious change in 
function but the technically suboptimal nature of both studies 
precludes definitive comparison. 

___ CTA Chest

IMPRESSION: 
1.  Suboptimal contrast timing decreases sensitivity to 
detection of filling
defects within the subsegmental pulmonary arterial branches.  No 
central
pulmonary embolus or right heart strain pattern.
2.  Moderate left and small right pleural effusions with 
associated
compressive atelectasis.
3.  Extensive lymphadenopathy, similar to most recent comparison 
examination,
compatible with patient's history of CLL.

___ Lower Extremity Duplex Ultrasound
IMPRESSION:  
Acute nonocclusive thrombus demonstrated throughout the right 
axillary vein, subclavian vein, and basilic vein with 
visualization of an intraluminal PICC line.

==============

WBC 2.8

BMP: K 5.2 (repeat 4.5), HCO3 33 (36)
TLS labs wnl: Uric acid 2.4, Phosph 3.5, Calcium 8.___ w/ ankylosing spondylitis, SAPHO syndrome, HTN and CLL w/ 
11q on ibrutinib who presented with rapid disease progression.

#CLL
#Pancytopenia
Rapidly progressive disease on ibrutinib with LN biopsy negative 
for Richter transformation to large cell lymphoma. He was 
initiated on venetoclax, day 1 = ___. This treatment was 
dose reduced initially by 50% for its interactions with 
diltiazem. He was started on 10 mg x 7 days, 20 mg x 3 days and 
then increased to 50 mg on ___. His course was complicated 
by pancytopenia, a known complication of venetoclax. Since he 
did not have the 50mg pills, he was treated with 100mg every 
other day. He was given filgrastim on ___ and ___ to support 
his ANC while on venetoclax. While on Venetoclax, he was 
monitored with frequent TLS/renal function labs, without 
evidence of lysis or kidney injury. He was given sevelamer 800 
mg TID to be taken with meals as well as allopurinol ___ mg 
daily, which were both continued on discharge. He was initially 
started on 100 mg prednisone daily (received x 5 days), which 
was tapered over the course of a week (last dose ___. In 
the setting of high dose prednisone and IVF for initiation of 
venetoclax, he developed marked peripheral volume overload and 
was started on 40 mg PO Lasix BID. Due to soft BPs, this Lasix 
was discontinued. If he continues to have peripheral edema as an 
outpatient, can consider restarting Lasix.

# Malignant Pleural Effusion
Prior to presentation, he was admitted to ___ 
___ for large left sided pleural effusion. He underwent 
removal of 1200 cc via thoracentesis, with cytology consistent 
with CLL. Upon discharge, he had a CT chest which remonstrated a 
moderate pleural effusion. During this admission, he had a 
repeat thoracentesis on ___, with removal of 1 L of sanguinous 
fluid. Pleural fluid studies exudative and consistent with CLL. 
He was initially continued on IV ceftriaxone, which was later 
discontinued as pleural studies from both OSH and ___ were 
without evidence of infection. His pleural effusion was 
monitored by symptom, O2 requirement and progression on CXR 
throughout the admission. He was evaluated on multiple 
subsequent occasions by interventional pulmonology, but did not 
require additional thoracentesis. He will follow up with IP at 
___ as an outpatient for further management on ___.

#New onset atrial fibrillation
#Sinus tachycardia
New onset atrial fibrillation with RVR into 170-180s during this 
admission. He was stabilized with a regimen of PO diltiazem and 
metoprolol, with IV diltiazem as needed during episodes of RVR. 
Given his a-fib was refractory to initial medication management, 
cardiology was consulted. He had an ECHO performed on ___ 
without evidence of thrombus, CHF or valvular abnormalities. 
A-fib felt to most likely be multifactorial in the setting of 
pleural effusion, malignancy, ibrutinib therapy. Given his 
relatively low risk of both stroke and bleeding, we did not 
initiate systemic anticoagulation in setting of ongoing marrow 
suppressive therapy and worsening thrombocytopenia. He was 
monitored on telemetry throughout the admission. He required 
careful titration of medications in setting of peripheral volume 
overload, IVF with venetoclax chemotherapy, hypoxia and soft 
BPs. After approximately 2 weeks in atrial fibrillation, he 
spontaneously converted into sinus rhythm, however continued to 
experience sinus tachycardia. CTA was obtained, which was 
without evidence of PE. Due to the interaction of diltiazem and 
venetoclax, as well as hypotension with high doses of diltiazem, 
we favored uptitration of metoprolol. He was ultimately well 
controlled on Metoprolol succinate 100mg. He will follow up with 
Dr. ___ at ___ Card___.

#Peripheral edema
#Marked lymphedema to BLE
#RLE skin tear
Peripheral edema present on admission, which worsened in the 
setting of high dose steroids and IVF during chemotherapy. 
Additionally, presence of a small skin tear on RLE, which 
appeared to be an erosion, which led to weeping fluid in the 
setting of his marked edema. He was evaluated by wound nurse who 
recommended daily dressing changes and use of ace bandages. He 
was initiated on treatment with furosemide 40 mg PO BID. This 
was discontinued prior to discharge in setting of soft BPs. It 
can be reconsidered in the outpatient setting if he continues to 
have persistent peripheral edema. He has follow up scheduled in 
the wound clinic on ___. He should continue daily 
dressing changes to BLE lymphedema wounds and elevate his legs 
when sitting. We have arranged ___ services to visit once weekly 
to reevaluate.

#PICC line erythema
Erythema surrounding PICC line site on his right inner arm. 
Completed cephalexin 500 mg QID x 5 days.

#Right upper extremity DVT
PICC line associated acute non-occlusive thrombus extending from 
right basilica vein to right axillary vein. Treated with 
lovenox.

#Hypogammaglobulinemia
SPEP with evidence of hypogammaglobulinemia. For prevention of 
infection, given course of IVIG x 3 doses while inpatient 
(___).

#Chronically elevated serum bicarbonate
Patient with apparent chronically elevated bicarbonate level. 
VBG with CO2 ___. CO2 retention is most likely secondary to 
hypoventilation in the setting of ankylosing spondylitis and 
SAPHO syndrome.

# Ankylosing Spondylitis
# SAPHO
Home percocet was held and he was given oxycodone PRN while 
inpatient.

# HTN
Discontinued home atenolol as started metoprolol per above.

Transitional Issues

secondary to pancytopenia
[ ] Consider need for further filgrastim to support ANC while 
receiving venetoclax
[ ] Reconsider anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation in

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to neurosurgery on ___ s/p fall off 
bicycle while intoxicated with TBI, bifrontal, bitemporal IPH 
and SDH along falx. He was transferred to the Neuro ICU for 
atrial fibrillation/tachycardia. Following improvement in the 
NICU, she was transferred to the step down unit, and eventually 
the floor where his neurologic exam remained stable. 

#TBI
Patient was admitted to neurosurgery to the ICU. He was started 
on Keppra and hypertonic saline for Na control. Repeat NCHCT was 
obtained 6 hours from prior which remained stable. The patient 
remained in the TSICU intubated and sedated. He was extubated on 
___. Repeat CTs on ___ and ___ were stable. Patient was 
reintubated on ___ for respiratory issues. Patient self 
extubated from a forceful cough and maintained his respiratory 
status on shovel mask. His pupils were dilated by ophthalmology 
on ___. He was reintubated on ___ and later extubated on 
___. MRI of the brain on ___ showed no evidence of stroke. 
He was restrated on gabapentin and Seroquel was decreased. His 
salt tabs were eventually weaned to off for normal sodium 
levels. Guardianship paperwork was started on ___, as the 
patient's ex-wife no longer wished to fulfill that role, however 
on ___, she agreed to continue being his HCP. On ___, he was 
unable to move his left upper extremity, and would only 
minimally withdraw to noxious stimuli. Head CT revealed a large 
chronic right sided subdural hematoma. The patient was taken to 
the OR urgently for right burr hole for evacuation. The OR was 
uncomplicated. Please see OMR for further intraoperative 
details. Postoperative imaging showed improvement and remained 
stable. The patient remained intubated postoperatively and was 
taken for a right MMA embolization the next day, on ___. This 
procedure was also uncomplicated. Please see OMR for further 
intraoperative details. The patient was extubated on ___. He 
remained neurologically stable and was transferred to the ___ 
on ___. The patient's neurological status improved while in 
___, and he was noted to be more alert and conversant. The 
patient's neurological status continued to improve in the NIMU 
as sedating medications were weaned off. The patient was 
transferred to the floor for further care awaiting disposition. 
On the floor, he had intermittent episodes of agitation and 
repeatedly tried to get out of bed. On ___, he fell onto the 
ground while trying to get out of bed, however, HCT was stable 
following the incident. He was re-evaluated by psychiatry who 
recommended increasing Depakote for agitation. On Depakote, LFTs 
became elevated. Depakote stopped on ___ per hepatology 
recommendations. Due to continued pain, gabapentin was titrated 
up as tolerated with a goal of 
returning the patient to his home dose of gabapentin. He was 
found to be picking at his incision, and this was closely 
monitored. Incision remained dry with granulation tissue. The 
patient was occasionally felt to be depressed, and when 
psychiatry was consulted they recommended outpatient follow up 
once patient is in rehab. Follow up will also be arranged with 
Dr. ___ in neurosurgery in approximately 4 weeks. He will 
return and a repeat HCT will be performed to assess for 
resolution of the SDH. At the time of discharge, he was 
ambulating with assistance using the walker, pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen and his neurologic exam remained 
stable. 

#Decreased Left Lower Extremity Movement
The patient had an MRI of the total spine in the setting of 
continued decreased movement of his left lower extremity, which 
was notable for syringohydromyelia and old blood products within 
the thoracic spine. Per patient's family, the patient was also 
ambulating previously with a cane. This is likely traumatic 
syringomyelia vs chronic arachnoiditis leading to syringomyelia. 
On ___, the patient was not moving his left lower extremity as 
well as the prior day and a CT head was ordered which revealed 
stable HCT. The change in mental status was likely due to opioid 
medications for PEG placement. Patient's LLE improved over the 
course of his hospital stay. However, the patient will need 
continued intensive physical therapy to increase mobility and 
strength, and to increase function in the left lower extremity. 
He is at significant risk for falls and should be maintained on 
fall precautions, with additional fall precautions such as a low 
bed at nighttime. 

#Fevers 
On ___ the patient spiked fever and was started on vanc/zosyn. 
He was pan cultured. Due to persistent tachycardia, blood 
cultures were obtained on ___ that showed staphylococcus, 
however this was likely a contaminate as blood cultures x3 were 
negative thereafter.  The patient was treated for an aspiration 
pneumonia with ceftriaxone. A CXR obtained on ___, 
demonstrated no focal consolidation or concern for pneumonia. 
Ceftriaxone was discontinued ___. The patient remained afebrile 
for the remainder of his hospitalization.

#Transaminitis
On ___, patient was noted to have elevated LFT's.  Hepatology 
was consulted who recommended discontinuing Depakote in the 
setting of hepatitis C and elevated LFT's. Repeat LFT's were 
trended, hepatitis panel was sent. Liver U/S was performed which 
revealed mild splenomegaly and normal morphology of liver 
without lesions noted. LFTs were checked daily while in hospital 
and were down trending since cessation of Depakote, however on 
monitoring on ___ they increased and were closely monitored 
for the remainder of his hospitalization. LFTs were also checked 
on ___ and showed slightly elevated AST and ALT. LFTs should 
be continued to be followed with his PCP to assess for rapid 
elevation. Caution should be used when using Depakote for mood 
stabilization as this previously resulted in significant LFT 
elevation.  

#ETOH withdrawal/agitation
The patient developed ETOH withdrawal and agitation while in the 
TSICU. He was started on Seroquel and Precedex drip. He was 
given small phenobarbital bolus x1, and was later started on a 
phenobarbital taper. The patient then continued on Seroquel and 
Clonidine with PRN Haldol IV. Psych was consulted on ___ for 
further recommendations. He was started on Depakote QHS on 
___, this dose was titrated per psychology recommendations 
according to patients response and agitation. Patient was 
discharged on Depakote 250mg Q12hrs, 25mg Seroquel PRN HS. On 
___, clonidine was titrated down to 0.1mg q8hrs per cardiology 
recs. On ___, the clonidine was further titrated down. 
Agitation improved over the course of his hospitalization. He is 
no longer requiring Seroquel, deptakote, or restraints. 

#Orbital roof fracture
Orbital roof fracture was noted on CT, ophthalmology and plastic 
surgery were consulted. Lateral canthotomy was lengthened. No 
globe injury was identified.  No urgent surgical intervention 
was recommended.  His pupils were dilated by ophthalmology on 
___ after extubation. Optho re-evaluated the patient on ___ 
to measure ocular pressures and findings were likely normal. 
Ophthalmology unable to fully assess visual acuity due to 
patient's metal status. They recommend follow up outpatient for 
a routine exam and patient as discharged with information to 
make this appointment. (See discharge info for phone number of 
clinic). 

#Left parietal bone fracture
ENT was consulted for recommendations on management of fracture. 
No acute intervention was recommended. He completed a course of 
Neomycin-Polymyxin-HC otic drops. There was no facial paralysis 
noted upon extubation. Patient needs follow-up with ENT for his 
Ossicular chain discontinuity. 

#New onset Afib
The patient developed new onset Atrial Fibrillation while in the 
TSICU. He was not a candidate for anticoagulation in the setting 
of recent TBI with contusions. On ___, due to persistent 
hypertension and tachycardia not controlled by IV
Metoprolol, and he was transferred to the NICU where he briefly 
required a Nicardipine, Diltiazem drip and Precedex. He later 
improved and was able to tolerate PO medications. On ___, the 
patient's HR dipped down into the 30's, but he remained 
asymptomatic. His PO Diltiazem was held. Overnight on the ___, 
he went back into atrial fibrillation and his PO Diltiazem was 
resumed at 30mg Q6hrs. Patient also on PO metoprolol tartrate, 
which was increased on ___ to 50mg q6hrs due to persistent 
afib with RVR. Based on cardiolgy recommendations, Metoprolol 
was further increased to 75 mg q6 hr. Patient to discuss 
anticoagulation options for Afib at outpatient follow up. On 
___, patient's HR's transiently down to ___ while sleeping, 
while awake HR 40-50s. Metoprolol decreased to 37.5mg q6h.

Based on cardiology recommendations, the patient was then 
transitioned to Digoxin 0.25, long acting digoxin 240 mg, and 
Metoprolol succinate 200 mg. Due to episodes of bradycardia the 
patient was then transitioned back to q6 dosing of metoprolol 
and diltiazem to prevent prolonged bradycardic episodes. Patient 
should follow up with a PCP to adjust these medications as 
needed. Patient will also need cardiology follow-up given 
persistent afib, and to titrate medications as needed. The 
patient should not be started on systemic anti-coagulation until 
cleared by neurosurgery. 

#Nutrition
The patient was evaluated by SLP, who recommended that he be 
NPO. An NG tube was placed, which the patient pulled out. 
Attempts were made to replace it x7, without success. GI was 
consulted and attempted to replace it, but was unsuccessful. It 
will be replaced under visualization on ___. Formal speech 
trials were attempted again however patient did not do well 
given oral secretions and altered mentation. After multiple 
failed attempts to replace NGT, the patient was brought to 
endoscopy suite with GI to place NJ tube. He was started on tube 
feedings with recommendations for nutrition. On the morning of 
___, the patient became acutely agitated and self-discontinued 
NJ tube despite restraints. However, he was then able to eat his 
meals with 1:1 RN supervision. SLP re-evaluated the patient on 
___, and continued to recommend NPO with trials under RN 
supervision. Due to acute decompensation from worsening ___ 
patient was again unable to safely intake PO. An NG tube was 
placed successfully post-operatively. Speech evaluated patient 
again post-operatively on ___ and recommended patient be NPO 
and PEG placement for continued nutritional support. ACS was 
consulted for PEG placement. Nutrition consult recommended 
temporary PPN until PEG placed. PEG was placed on ___ without 
issues. When CXR was obtained and showed increased air under the 
right hemi diaphragm, ACS evaluated the patient and felt that 
findings were not concerning. On ___ the patient was more 
awake, and SLP cleared for sips of water. Over the subsequent 
few days, this swallowing improved, and he was cleared for a 
ground diet. Tubefeeds were changed to being cycled overnight. 
Cleared for regular diet and thin liquids with supervision on 
___. Tolerating diet with 1:1 supervision, PEG remains in 
place but not currently receiving tube feedings. Patient's PEG 
site looked red and the bumper was not visible on ___. ACS was 
paged who pulled back the bumper and removed the T bumper and 
replaced it with a star bumper on ___. ACS did not 
recommend prophylactic abx at this time as WBC low and no signs 
of infection. Patient will continue with PEG placement for at 
least ___ weeks post placement, then may be removed. Nursing 
performed PEG tube checks every shift during hospitalization. 
The patient will need to seen by ___ at ___ in ___ weeks for 
PEG removal. Please call to schedule outpatient appointment.

Discharge Diagnosis:
TBI, bifrontal IPH, SDH, Orbital roof fracture with R globe 
proptosis, right superior orbital rim fx, Left parietal bone fx, 
extends to temporal and mastoid bone, thoracic syrinx, 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Traumatic Brain Injury

Surgery
 You underwent a surgery called a craniotomy to have blood 
removed from your brain. 
 It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
 Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage from the incision.

Activity
 We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
 You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
 You make take a shower.
 No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
 If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
 No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
 Please do NOT take any other blood thinning medication other 
than Aspirin (Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the 
neurosurgeon. 
 You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
 You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
remembering new information.
 Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 
 Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.
 Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Headaches:
 Headache is one of the most common symptoms after traumatic 
brain injury. Headaches can be long-lasting. 
 Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 
 Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but 
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed 
by your doctor. 
 There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


More Information about Brain Injuries:
 You were given information about headaches after TBI and the 
impact that TBI can have on your family.
 If you would like to read more about other topics such as: 
sleeping, driving, cognitive problems, emotional problems, 
fatigue, seizures, return to school, depression, balance, or/and 
sexuality after TBI, please ask our staff for this information 
or visit ___

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

then behaved aggressively toward police officers. It took six

patient denies any head strike or injury. He was brought to the

In the ED, initial vital signs were 98.5, 60, 136/68, 17, 98%

On transfer, vital signs were 98.0, 92, 144/77, 18, 100% RA.  

On interview, patient reports that he is feeling well with no
