___ Cardiovascular Transthoracic Echo Report 
The left atrial volume index is moderately increased. The right 
atrium is mildly enlarged. There is no evidence for an atrial 
septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with a normal cavity size. There is 
normal regional and global left ventricular systolic function. 
The visually estimated left ventricular ejection fraction is 
>=65%. Left ventricular cardiac index is normal (>2.5 L/min/m2). 
There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. 
Normal right ventricular cavity size with normal free wall 
motion. The aortic sinus is mildly dilated with mildly dilated 
ascending aorta. The aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal. There is SEVERE 
aortic valve stenosis (valve area index less than 0.6 cm2/m2). 
There is an eccentric, anterior mitral leaflet directed jet of 
mild to moderate [___] aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve 
leaflets appear structurally normal with no mitral valve 
prolapse. There is trivial mitral regurgitation. The tricuspid 
valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is physiologic 
tricuspid
regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure 
is normal. There is no pericardial effusion.
IMPRESSION: Mild to moderate left ventricular hypertrophy with 
normal global/regional systolic function. Severe aortic 
stenosis. Mildly dilated thoracic aorta. Mild to moderate aortic 
regurgitation.

___ TAVR AND TORSO CTA 
FINDINGS:  
EXTRACARDIAC FINDINGS: 
CT CHEST WITH CONTRAST: Visualized thyroid gland is 
unremarkable.  There is no supraclavicular, axillary, 
mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.  Heart is normal in size. 
 There is no pericardial effusion.  There are mild-to-moderate 
coronary artery calcifications.  As discussed below, the aortic 
valve is tricuspid and heavily calcified with thickening of the 
leaflets.  No suggestion of left atrial thrombus.  There is no 
pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  There is bibasilar 
atelectasis without concerning parenchymal consolidation or 
nodularity.  Airways are patent to the subsegmental level.  
There is no centrally located pulmonary embolus.  Pulmonary 
vasculature is enlarged, with main, left, and right pulmonary 
arteries measuring 3.1, 3.0, and 2.8 cm, respectively.  These 
findings are suggestive of sequela of pulmonary arterial 
hypertension.  Soft tissues demonstrate symmetric gynecomastia, 
expected in this patient with known cirrhosis.  Additionally, 
there are significant paraesophageal varices, which are 
partially visualized in the lower chest, in the region of the 
esophageal hiatus.   
CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS WITH CONTRAST: Please see dictation from 
concurrent CTA 
abdomen and pelvis for full description of subdiaphragmatic 
findings and 
osseous structures in this region.  
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: There are no concerning sclerotic or lytic 
lesions in the thoracic spine or thoracic cage.  No acute 
compression deformity or acute fracture of the major structures 
of the bony thorax.  
CTA: Due to severe liver cirrhosis, there is poor arterial 
timing, which limits the cardiac CTA portion of this exam.  
Overall, cardiac portion of this exam is nondiagnostic. 
CARDIAC: Heart is normal in size.  Mild-to-moderate coronary 
artery 
calcifications are present.  Aortic valve is tricuspid and 
heavily calcified with thickened leaflets.  No suggestion of 
left atrial thrombus on this limited exam.  Pericardium is 
normal without pericardial effusion. 
PULMONARY ARTERIES: Pulmonary vasculature is enlarged, as above. 
Findings 
likely represent sequela of pulmonary arterial hypertension. 
AORTA:  The thoracic and abdominal aorta are normal in size with 
mild 
calcifications. 
MEASUREMENTS: To follow an addendum pending 3D reformats. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Aortic valve stenosis without evidence of aortic aneurysm. 
Cardiac portion of the examination is limited due to poor 
arterial contrast timing due to severe liver cirrhosis.  If 
necessary for preprocedural planning, this portion of the exam 
can be repeated. 
2. Measurements of subclavian and femoral arteries to follow in 
an addendum pending 3D reformats. 
3. Gynecomastia and paraesophageal varices, consistent with 
sequela of known cirrhosis. 

___ CTA ABD & PELVIS 
ABDOMEN: 
HEPATOBILIARY: Liver is shrunken and nodular consistent with 
cirrhosis.  There is relative hypertrophy of the caudate lobe.  
No focal liver lesions are seen. No intra or extrahepatic 
biliary dilation.  Gallbladder contains gallstones but is 
otherwise unremarkable.  
PANCREAS: The pancreas has normal attenuation throughout, 
without evidence of focal lesions or pancreatic ductal 
dilatation.  There is no peripancreatic stranding.  
SPLEEN: Spleen is markedly enlarged measuring up to 23.1 cm, but 
is otherwise unremarkable.  Extensive perisplenic varices are 
noted. 
ADRENALS: The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size 
and shape.  
URINARY: Right kidney is normal in size and shape without 
evidence of 
hydronephrosis.  Left kidney is markedly atrophic.  A simple 
cyst in the 
interpolar region of the right kidney measures up to 3.6 cm.  A 
peripherally calcified cyst in the lower pole of the left kidney 
measures up to 1.6 cm.  
GASTROINTESTINAL: Small to medium-sized hiatal hernia.  Stomach 
is otherwise unremarkable.  Small bowel loops demonstrate normal 
caliber, wall thickness, and enhancement throughout.  The colon 
and rectum are within normal limits. The appendix is normal. 
There is small volume abdominopelvic ascites.   
PELVIS: The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable. 
  
REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS: Prostate contains a large coarse 
calcification but is 
otherwise unremarkable.  The left seminal vesicle is very 
smaller absent 
suggesting that the left renal abnormality may be congenital.  
LYMPH NODES: There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric 
lymphadenopathy.  There is no pelvic or inguinal 
lymphadenopathy.  
VASCULAR: There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Mild 
atherosclerotic disease is noted.  The celiac axis is focally 
dilated proximally measuring up to 15 mm, unchanged.  The right 
common iliac artery is mildly ectatic measuring up to 19 mm in 
diameter.  Previously seen thrombus within the main portal vein 
as well as of the SMV the and splenic veins are not well 
appreciated on this exam due to arterial contrast timing.  
Extensive upper abdominal varices are noted. 
BONES: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or 
acute fracture.  
SOFT TISSUES: Moderate symmetric gynecomastia is noted.  Fat 
containing 
umbilical hernia is noted. 
IMPRESSION:  
1. Cirrhosis with sequela of portal hypertension including 
marked 
splenomegaly, extensive upper abdominal varices, and small 
volume 
abdominopelvic ascites.  Previously seen thrombus within the 
main portal vein, SMV, and splenic veins is not well 
demonstrated on this arterial phase exam.  
2. Dilatation of the celiac axis and right common iliac artery.  
Followup 
ultrasound should be considered for surveillance in 1 to ___ 
years.

No esophageal or gastric varices. Portal hypertensive

Multiple nonbleeding diverticula in the sigmoid colon. A few

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
=======================================================
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with history of cryptogenic 
cirrhosis (Child ___ B, MELD 15 on admission) decompensated by 
varices s/p banding (___) and progressive non-occlusive portal 
vein/SMV thrombosis, who presented for evaluation for 
thrombecty/TIPS given worsening thrombosis. It was determined 
that TIPS would be the optimal procedure for his thrombosis, but 
would not be done unless he was a liver transplant candidate. 
Furthermore, he has severe AS and it was felt that he required 
AVR prior to any other procedures given his high risk. He 
partially completed evaluation for TAVR and liver 
transplantation while he was admitted, with plan to complete the 
evaluation as an outpatient given his clinical stability. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=======================================================
#Portal vein thrombosis
#SMV thrombosis 
Patient has a history of nonocclusive portal vein/SMV 
thrombosis, first noted on imaging in ___. Between ___ and 
___, he had progression of fibrosis including portal 
and superior mesenteric veins. He was admitted for consideration 
of thrombectomy versus TIPS by ___. The ___ team felt that 
thrombectomy would be unlikely to provide benefit and thus 
recommended TIPS procedure. However, as noted below, the patient 
was found to have severe aortic stenosis so the TIPS was 
deferred until repair of his aortic valve. 

#Severe aortic stenosis
Last TTE in ___ demonstrated moderate to severe aortic 
valve stenosis. On admission the patient endorsed 
lightheadedness and dyspnea on exertion limiting his daily 
function, thought to be secondary to his AS. Repeat TTE during 
this admission found progressive ALS with valve area 1.1 cm2. 
Cardiology and structural heart teams were consulted and felt 
that he was a good TAVR candidate. He was evaluated by cardiac 
surgery and found to be not a surgical AVR candidate. He also 
underwent TAVR CT and left heart cath for planning purposes. His 
coronary angiography was overall normal with only 30% stenosis 
at the proximal left circumflex and no other clinically 
significant disease. Per the cardiology structural team they 
will plan on reviewing his CT chest again and consider repeating 
it if necessary. They will arrange his TAVR as an outpatient. 

#Acute on chronic kidney injury
On admission the patient's creatinine was 1.3 with a baseline of 
1.0-1.2 up to ___, after which time his creatinine remains 
elevated (1.3-1.5). Etiology was unclear but was felt to be 
secondary to hypovolemia in the setting of cirrhosis and 
diuresis. His diuretics were held on admission without 
improvement in his creatinine. He was also noted to be 
hypotensive with systolic blood pressures ___ on hospital day 2. 
He was started on midodrine and received albumin with 
improvement of his Cr back to baseline. 

#Hypotension
On admission the patient was made n.p.o. for possible endoscopy. 
Overnight he became hypotensive to the ___ (baseline 
systolic 80-100). He was given IV fluids and albumin with 
subsequent improvement. As above, during admission his diuretics 
were held and he was given small boluses of albumin to maintain 
euvolemia due to his tenuous volume status secondary to 
cirrhosis and aortic stenosis. He had no further episodes of 
hypotension.

#Cryptogenic cirrhosis (Childs B, MELD 15)
Hx of decompensation by variceal bleed in ___ s/p banding and 
ascites. As above his home Lasix and spironolactone were held. 
He was maintained on a low sodium diet. He was continued on 
lactulose 30 ml TID and rifaximin. He is potentially a 
transplant candidate, test workup was initiated in the hospital 
including infectious serologies, malignancy screening, lipid 
panel, PSA, Panorex, PFTs, EGD/Colonoscopy and TTE.

Certainly! Here are the reasons for the ICD-10 codes based on the evidence from the medical record:

**I81: Portal vein thrombosis**
- **Reason:** The patient has a history of nonocclusive portal vein thrombosis, which was first noted on imaging and progressed over time. The patient was admitted for consideration of thrombectomy or TIPS due to worsening thrombosis.

**I5033: Acute on chronic diastolic (congestive) heart failure**
- **Reason:** This code does not seem to be directly supported by the medical record. The patient has severe aortic stenosis and hypotension but no specific mention of diastolic heart failure.

**I82890: Acute embolism and thrombosis of other specified veins**
- **Reason:** The patient has a history of nonocclusive superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis, which is a specified vein. This code is appropriate for the thrombosis of the SMV.

**K766: Portal hypertension**
- **Reason:** The patient has a history of portal hypertension, evidenced by the presence of varices, ascites, and splenomegaly. The medical record mentions that the patient has portal hypertension as a complication of cirrhosis.

**K7469: Other cirrhosis of liver**
- **Reason:** The patient has a diagnosis of cryptogenic cirrhosis, which is classified under other cirrhosis of the liver. The medical record provides a detailed history of the patient"s cirrhosis and its complications.

**Z87891: Personal history of nicotine dependence**
- **Reason:** There is no mention of nicotine dependence in the medical record. This code is not applicable.

**Z794: Long term (current) use of insulin**
- **Reason:** The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, but there is no indication of long-term use of insulin. The patient was managed on Humalog sliding scale during the hospital stay.

**M109: Gout, unspecified**
- **Reason:** The patient has a past medical history of gout and is on allopurinol, which supports the use of this code.

**K219: Gastro-esophageal reflux disease without esophagitis**
- **Reason:** The patient has a history of GERD and is on pantoprazole, which supports the use of this code.

**D509: Iron deficiency anemia, unspecified**
- **Reason:** The patient has a history of iron deficiency anemia and is on ferrous sulfate, which supports the use of this code.

**I959: Hypotension, unspecified**
- **Reason:** The patient experienced hypotension during the hospital stay, which was managed with IV fluids and albumin. This supports the use of this code.

**E861: Hypovolemia**
- **Reason:** The patient had hypovolemia, likely secondary to cirrhosis and diuresis, which was managed with albumin and midodrine. This supports the use of this code.

**N189: Chronic kidney disease, unspecified**

Discharge Instructions:
 You were admitted for a trans catheter aortic valve replacement 
(TAVR) to treat your aortic valve stenosis which was done on 
___. 

 It is very important to take all of your heart healthy 
medications. In particular, you are now taking 325mg aspirin 
daily. This medication helps to prevent blood clots from forming 
on the new valve. If you stop this medication or miss ___ dose, 
you risk causing a blood clot forming on your new valve. This 
could cause it to malfunction and it may be life threatening. 
Please do not stop taking aspirin without taking to your heart 
doctor. 

 You will need prophylactic antibiotics prior to any dental 
procedure. Please inform your dentist about your cardiac 
procedure, and obtain a prescription from your doctor before any 
procedure. 

 Please weigh yourself every day in the morning after you go to 
the bathroom and before you get dressed. If your weight goes up 
by more than 3 lbs in 1 day or more than 5 lbs in 3 days, please 
call your heart doctor or your primary care doctor and alert 
them to this change. 

 You will also need to have close follow up with your primary 
care doctor, please see below for appointment details. If you 
have urgent questions that are related to your recovery from 
your procedure or are experiencing any symptoms that are 
concerning to you and you think you may need to return to the 
hospital, please call the ___ HeartLine at ___ to 
speak to a cardiologist or cardiac nurse practitioner. 

 It has been a pleasure to have participated in your care and we 
wish you the best with your health.

cot:
K921: Melena
- Reason: The patient presented with melena, which is explicitly mentioned in the chief complaint and throughout the hospital course. The labs show a stable hemoglobin level, and the patient was treated with pantoprazole and octreotide for the melena.

I81: Portal vein thrombosis
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of non-occlusive portal vein thrombosis, and the CT abdomen/pelvis confirmed the presence of nonocclusive thrombus in the portal veins, portal splenic confluence, and superior mesenteric vein (SMV).

K7469: Other cirrhosis of liver
- Reason: The patient has a history of cryptogenic cirrhosis, which is mentioned multiple times in the medical record, including the past medical history and the clinical implications section. The CT abdomen/pelvis also shows cirrhosis with sequelae of portal hypertension.

R079: Chest pain, unspecified
- Reason: The patient reported intermittent chest pain, and an EKG showed a new left bundle branch block (LBBB). Although troponins were negative and there was no evidence of acute coronary syndrome, the chest pain is still a significant issue that was evaluated during the hospital stay.

I350: Nonrheumatic aortic (valve) stenosis
- Reason: The patient has a history of severe aortic valve stenosis and underwent a transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). The TTE during the hospital stay confirmed a well-seated, normal functioning TAVR with mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and normal biventricular function.

N189: Chronic kidney disease, unspecified
- Reason: The patient has one functional kidney and a creatinine level at the upper limit of baseline, indicating chronic kidney disease (CKD). This is also mentioned in the chronic/stable issues section.

M109: Gout, unspecified
- Reason: The patient has a history of gout and is on allopurinol for management. This is noted in the past medical history and the discharge medications.

K219: Gastro-esophageal reflux disease without esophagitis
- Reason: The patient is on pantoprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), for the management of gastro-esophageal reflux disease (GERD). This is mentioned in the discharge medications and the chronic/stable issues section.

D509: Iron deficiency anemia, unspecified
- Reason: The patient has a documented history of iron deficiency anemia, and the iron supplementation (ferrous gluconate) was held initially and then restarted upon discharge. This is noted in the past medical history and the discharge medications.

E119: Type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications
- Reason: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and is diet-controlled. This is mentioned in the past medical history and the discharge medications.
